Oxford transcription team, 1992-1998: Peter Robinson, Elizabeth Solopova, Lorna Stevenson, with contributions from James McCabe, Hubert Stadler, Cathy Swires, Paul and Maureen Watry, Laura Wright, Diana Wyatt and Simon Horobin
Sheffield transcription team, 1992-1998, led by Norman Blake: Michael Pidd and Estelle Stubbs, with Linda Cross, Claire Thomson and Simon Horobin
De Montfort transcription team, 1998-2005: Peter Robinson, Barbara Bordalejo, Orietta Da Rold, Gavin Cole, Pip Willcox, Jennifer Marshall, Takako Kato, Jacob Thaisen, Nicole Green
University of Saskatchewan team, 2010-2013: Peter Robinson and Barbara Bordalejo
Virgina Tech team, led by Daniel W. Mosser
New York University team, led by David Hoover and Martha Rust, 2003-2006.

Brigham Young University transcription team, 1995-2006, led by Paul Thomas: Sara Black, Jessica Cox, Barbara Christiansen, Kerry Clift Spencer*, Heidi Elldredge, Leona Fisher Sankhla, Kela Flint*, Melissa Gallup, Shannon Harris, Rebecca Johnson, Mary Jorgensen, Darin Merrill*, Wesley Pack*, Jared Perkins, Jon Penny, Randall Rogers, Ryan Rowberry*, Sara Slack, Carie Soderquist Jackson*, Kat Southerland, Matt Tenney, Briton Wright, John Young. Asterisks after names denote those who supervised other transcribers.

Adam Mickiewicz University, Poznan, transcription team, 2007-2010: (names to be supplied), with support from Adam Mickiewicz University and the The Polish Ministry for Science and Higher Education, grant N104 045 32/4256.
Nila Vazquez Gonzalez, University of Murcia.
Institute of Book Studies and Textual Research of the University of Münster, Germany, c. 2000-2004,led by Gabriele Müller Oberhauser; transcribed by Ulrike Grassnick.

University of Sheffield, 1994-1999, led by Norman Blake: Michael Pidd and Estelle Stubbs, with Linda Cross, Claire Thomson, Orietta Da Rold and Simon Horobin. In partnership with the Canterbury Tales Project, at that time led by Norman Blake in partnership with Peter Robinson and Elizabeth Solopova (up to 1998), and using images and other resources supplied by the Project, the Sheffield team transcribed eight manuscripts in full (Ad3, Corpus, Dd, Gg, Ellesmere, Ha4, Hengwrt, Lansdowne), sections of some seven other manuscripts, and all manuscripts of the Franklin's Tale. No part of these transcripts is contained in this iteration of the Project.

div.l: (base) Was risen / and romed in a chambre anheigh
(base) In which / he al the noble Citee seigh
(base) And eek the gardyn / ful of braunches greene
(base) Ther as / the fresshe Emelye the sheene
(base) Was in hir walk / and romed vp and down
(base) This sorweful prisoner / this Palamoun
(base) This wooful louere this Palamon
(base) Gooth in the chambre / romyng to and fro
(base) And to hymself / compleynyng of his wo
(base) That he was born / ful ofte he seyde allas
(base) And so bifel / by auenture / or cas
(base) That thurgh a wyndow / thikke of many a barre
(base) Of Iren greet and square as any sparre
(base) He caste his eye / vpon Emelya
(base) And therwithal he bleynte / and cryde . A .
(base) As thogh / he stongen weere / vnto the herte
(base) ¶ And with that cry / Arcite anoon vp sterte
(base) And seyde cosyn myn / what eyleth thee
(base) That art so pale / and deedly on to see
(base) Why cridestow / who hath thee doon offence
(base) For goddes loue / tak al in pacience
(base) Oure prison / for it may noon oother be
(base) Fortune / hath yeuen vs this aduersitee
(base) Som wikked aspect or disposicioun
(base) Of Saturne / by som constellacioun
(base) Hath yeuen vs this / althogh we hadde it sworn
(base) So stood the heuene / whan that we were born
(base) We mote endure it this is the short and playn
(base) This Palamoun answerde / and seyde agayn
(base) ¶ Cosyn for sothe / of this opinioun
(base) Thow hast a vayn ymaginacioun
(base) This prisoun / caused me noght to crye
(base) But I was hurt right now / thurgh out myn Iye
(base) In to myn herte / that wol my bane be
(base) The fairnesse / of that lady that I se
(base) Yond in the gardyn / romen to and fro
(base) Is cause / of al my cryyng and my wo
(base) I noot wher she be womman / or goddesse
(base) But Venus / is it soothly / as I gesse
(base) And therwithal / on knees down he fil
(base) And seyde / Venus if it be thy wil
(base) Yow in this gardyn / thus to transfigure
(base) Bifore me / sorweful wrecched creature
(base) Out of this prisoun / help that we may scape
(base) And if so be / my destynee be shape
(base) By eterne word / to dyen in prisoun
(base) Of oure lynage / haue som compassioun
(base) That is so lowe ybroght by tirannye
(base) ¶ And with that word / Arcite gan espye
(base) Where as this lady / romed to and fro
(base) And with that sighte / hir beautee hurte hym so
(base) That if that Palamon / was wounded soore
(base) Arcite is hurt . as muche as he / or moore
(base) And with a syk / . he seyde pitously
(base) The fresshe beautee / sleeth me sodeynly
(base) Of hire / that rometh in the yonder place
(base) And but I haue / hir mercy / and hir grace
(base) That I may seen hire / at the leeste weye
(base) I nam but deed / ther nys namoore to seye
(base) ¶ This Palamon / whan he tho wordes herde
(base) Despitously / he loked / and answerde
(base) Wheither seistow this / in ernest or in pley
(base) ¶ Nay quod Arcite / in ernest by my fey
(base) God help me so / me list ful yuele pleye
(base) This Palamon / gan knytte his browes tweye
(base) ¶ It were to thee quod he / no greet honour
(base) For to be fals / ne for to be traytour
(base) To me / that am thy cosyn and thy brother
(base) Ysworn ful depe / and ech of vs til oother
(base) That neuere / for to dyen in the peyne
(base) Til that the deeth / departe shal vs tweyne
(base) Neither of vs / in loue to hyndre oother
(base) Ne in noon oother caas / my leeue brother
(base) But that thow sholdest trewely forthre me
(base) In euery caas / as I shal forthren thee
(base) This was thyn ooth / and myn also certeyn
(base) I woot right wel / thow darst it nat withseyn
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Thus artow of my conseil / out of doute
(base) And now / thow woldest falsly been aboute
(base) To loue my lady / whom I loue and serue
(base) And euere shal / til that myn herte sterue
(base) Now certes false Arcite / thow shalt nat so
(base) I loued hire first and tolde thee my wo
(base) As to my conseil / and my brother sworn
(base) To forthre me / as I haue told biforn
(base) For which / thow art ybounden / as a knyght
(base) To helpe me / if it laye in thy myght
(base) Or ellis artow fals / I dar wel sayn
(base) This Arcite / ful proudly spak agayn
(base) ¶ Thow shalt quod he / be rather fals than I
(base) And thow art fals / I telle thee outrely
(base) For paramour / I loued hire first er thow
(base) What wiltow seyn / thow woost nat yet now
(base) Wheither she be a womman / or goddesse
(base) Thyn is / affeccioun of holynesse
(base) And myn is loue / as to a creature
(base) For which / I tolde thee myn auenture
(base) As to my cosyn / and my brother sworn
(base) I pose / that thow louedest hire biforn
(base) Wostow nat wel / the olde clerkes sawe
(base) That who shal / yeue a louere any lawe
(base) Quis / legem det amantibz
(base) Loue is a gretter lawe / by my pan
(base) Than may be yeue / to any erthely man
(base) And therfore / posityf lawe / and swich decree
(base) Is broke alday for loue / in ech degree
(base) A man moot nedes loue / maugree his heed
(base) He may nat fleen it / thogh he sholde be deed
(base) Al be she mayde / wydwe / or ellis wyf
(base) And eek it is nat likly / al thy lyf
(base) To stonden in hir grace / namoore shal I
(base) For wel thow woost thy self verraily
(base) That thow and I / been dampned to prisoun
(base) Perpetuelly / vs gayneth no raunsoun
(base) We stryue / as dide the houndes / for the boon
(base) They foghte alday / and yet hir part was noon
(base) Ther cam a kyte / whil that they were so wrothe
(base) That bar awey the boon / bitwix hem bothe
(base) And therfore / at the kynges court my brother
(base) Ech man for hymself / ther is noon oother
(base) Loue if thee lest . for I loue / and ay shal
(base) And soothly / leue brother this is al
(base) Heere in this prisoun / moote we endure
(base) And euerich of vs / take his auenture
(base) ¶ Greet was the stryf / and long bitwix hem tweye
(base) If that I hadde leyser for to seye
(base) But to theffect it happed on a day
(base) To telle it yow / as shortly as I may
(base) A worthy duc . that highte Parotheus
(base) That felawe was / vnto Duc Theseus
(base) Syn thilke day / that they were children lyte
(base) Was come to Atthenes / his felawe to visite
(base) And for to pleye / as he was wont to do
(base) For in this world / he loued no man so
(base) And he loued hym / as tendrely agayn
(base) So wel they loued / as olde bookes sayn
(base) That whan that oon was deed / soothly to telle
(base) His felawe wente / and soghte hym down in helle
(base) But of that storie / list me noght to write
(base) Duc Parotheus / loued wel Arcite
(base) And hadde hym knowe at Thebes / yeer by yere
(base) And finally / at requeste and prayere
(base) Of Parotheus / withouten any raunsoun
(base) Duc Theseus / hym leet out of prisoun
(base) Frely to goon / wher that hym liste oueral
(base) In swich a gyse / as I yow tellen shal
(base) This was the forward / pleynly for tendite
(base) Bitwixe Theseus / and hym Arcite
(base) That if so weere that Arcite weere yfounde
(base) Euere in his lyf by day / or nyght or stounde
(base) In any contree / of this Theseus
(base) And he weere caught . it was acorded thus
(base) That with a swerd / he sholde lese his heed
(base) Ther nas noon oother / remedye ne reed
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) But taketh his leue / and homward he hym spedde
(base) Lat hym be war / his nekke lyth to wedde
(base) Hit were a gret thing to telle and to wite
(base) ¶ How greet a sorwe / suffreth now Arcite
(base) The deeth he feeleth / thurgh his herte smyte
(base) He wepeth / wayleth / cryeth pitously
(base) To sleen hymself he wayteth pryuely
(base) He seyde allas / the day that I was born
(base) Now is my prisoun / worse than biforn
(base) Now is me shape / eternally to dwelle
(base) Noght in purgatorie / but in helle
(base) Allas / that euere knew I Parotheus
(base) For ellis / hadde I dwelled with Theseus
(base) Yfettred in his prisoun eueremo
(base) Thanne hadde I been in blisse / and nat in wo
(base) Oonly the sighte of hire / whom that I serue
(base) Thogh that I neuere / hir grace may disserue
(base) Wolde haue suffised / right ynogh for me
(base) ¶ O deere cosyn / Palamon / quod he
(base) Thyn is the victorie / of this auenture
(base) Ful blisfully / in prisoun maystow dure
(base) In prison ; / nay certes / but in paradys
(base) Wel hath Fortune / yturned thee / the dys
(base) That hast the sighte of hire / and I thabsence
(base) For possible is / syn thow hast hire presence
(base) And art a knyght a worthy and an able
(base) That by som caas / syn Fortune is chaungeable
(base) Thow mayst to thy desir / som tyme atteyne
(base) But I / that am exiled and bareyne
(base) Of alle grace / and in so greet despeyr
(base) That ther nys Erthe / water / fyr / ne Eyr
(base) Ne creature / that of hem maked is
(base) That may me helpe / or do confort in this
(base) Wel oghte I sterue / in wanhope / and distresse
(base) Farwel my lyf / my lust and my gladnesse
(base) ¶ Allas / why pleynen folk so / in cōmmune
(base) On purueiance of god / or of Fortune
(base) That yeueth hem ful ofte / in many a gyse
(base) Wel bettre / than they kan hem self deuyse
(base) ¶ Som man desireth / for to haue richesse
(base) That cause is ofte / of his moerdre / or gret siknesse
(base) And som man wolde / out of his prison fayn
(base) That in his hous / is of his meynee slayn
(base) Infinite harmes / been in this matere
(base) We woot nat what thyng that we prayen heere
(base) We fare as he / that dronke is as a Mous
(base) A dronke man woot wel / he hath an hous
(base) But he noot which the righte wey is thider
(base) And to a dronke man / . the wey is slider
(base) And certes / in this world / so faren we
(base) We seken faste / after felicitee
(base) But we goon wrong ful ofte trewely
(base) Thus may we seyn alle / and nameliche I
(base) That wende / and hadde a greet opinioun
(base) That if I myghte / scapen fro prisoun
(base) Thanne hadde I been in ioye / and parfit heele
(base) Ther now / I am exiled fro my wele
(base) Syn that / I may nat seen yow Emelie
(base) I nam but deed / ther nys no remedie
(base) ¶ Vpon that oother syde Palamon
(base) Whan that he wiste / Arcite was agon
(base) Swich sorwe he maketh / that the grete tour
(base) Resowneth / of his yowlyng and clamour
(base) The pure fettres / of his shynes grete
(base) Were / of his bittre salte teeris wete
(base) Allas quod he / Arcita cosyn myn
(base) Of al oure stryf / god woot the fruyt is thyn
(base) Thow walkest now / in Thebes at thy large
(base) And of my wo / thow yeuest litel charge
(base) Thow mayst syn thou hast wisdom / and manhede
(base) Assemblen / al the folk of oure kynrede
(base) And make a werre / so sharp / on this Citee
(base) That by som auenture / or som tretee
(base) Thow mayst haue hire / to lady and to wyf
(base) For whom / that I moste nedes lese my lyf
(base) For as by wey / of possibilitee
(base) Sith thow art at thy large / of prisoun free
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) And art a lord / greet is thyn auantage
(base) Moore than is myn / that sterue here in a cage
(base) For I moot wepe / and waille whil I lyue
(base) With al the wo / that prison may me yeue
(base) And eek wᵗith peyne / that loue me yeueth also
(base) That doubleth / al my torment and my wo
(base) Ther with / the fyr of Ialousie vp sterte
(base) With Inne his brest and hente hym by the herte
(base) So woodly / that he lyk was to byholde
(base) The Boxtree / or the Asshen dede / and colde
(base) ¶ Thanne seyde he / o crewel goddes / that gouerne
(base) This world / with byndyng of youre word eterne
(base) And writen / in the table of Atthamaıı̄unt
(base) Youre parlement . and youre eterne graıı̄unt
(base) What is man kynde / moore vnto yow holde
(base) Than is the sheep / that rowketh in the folde
(base) For slayn is man / right as another beest
(base) And dwelleth eek in prison and arrest
(base) And hath siknesse / and greet aduersitee
(base) And ofte tymes / giltlees pardee
(base) ¶ What gouernance / is in this prescience
(base) That giltlees / tormenteth Innocence
(base) And yet encreeceth this / al my penance
(base) That man is bounden / to his obseruance
(base) For goddes sake / to letten of his wille
(base) Ther as a beest may al his lust fulfille
(base) And whan a beest is deed / it hath no peyne
(base) But man after his deeth / moot wepe and pleyne
(base) Thogh in this world / he haue care and wo
(base) Withouten doute / it moot stonden so
(base) The answere of this / lete I to diuynys
(base) But wel I woot that in this world / greet pyne is
(base) ¶ Allas / I se a serpent or a theef /
(base) That many a trewe man / hath doon mescheef
(base) Goon at his large / and where hym lust may turne
(base) But I moot been in prison / thurgh Saturne
(base) And eek thurgh Iuno / Ialous / and eek wood
(base) That hath destroyed / wel neigh al the blood
(base) Of Thebes / with his waste walles wyde
(base) And Venus / sleeth me / on that oother syde
(base) For Ialousie / and feere / of hym Arcite
(base) ¶ Now wol I stynte / of Palamon alite
(base) And lete hym / in his prisoun stille dwelle
(base) And of Arcita / forth I wol yow telle
(base) ¶ The Somer / and the nyghtes longe
(base) Encreecen / double wise / the peynes stronge
(base) Bothe of the louere / and the prisoner
(base) I noot which hath / the sorwefuller myster
(base) For soothly for to seyn / this Palamon
(base) Perpetuelly / is dampned to prisoun
(base) In cheynes / and in fettres / to been deed
(base) And Arcite / is exiled / vpon his heed
(base) For eueremo / as out of that contree
(base) Ne neueremo / ne shal his lady see
(base) ¶ Yow loueris / axe I now / this questioun
(base) Who hath the worse / Arcite / or Palamoun
(base) That oon may seen his lady / day by day
(base) But in prisoun / moot he dwelle alway
(base) That oother / where hym list may ride or go
(base) But seen his lady / shal he neuere mo
(base) Now demeth as yow list ye that kan
(base) For I wol telle forth / as I bigan
(base) ¶ Explicit prima pars ~
(base) ¶ Sequitur pars secunda ~
(base) ¶ Whan that Arcite / to Thebes comen was
(base) Ful ofte a day / he swelte / and seyde allas
(base) For seen his lady / shal he neuere mo
(base) And shortly / to concluden al his wo
(base) So muchel sorwe / hadde neuere creature
(base) That is or shal / whil that the world may dure
(base) ¶ His sleep / his mete / his drynke / is hym biraft
(base) That leene he weex / and drye as is a shaft
(base) Hise eyen holwe / and grisly to biholde
(base) His hewe falow / and pale as asshen colde
(base) And solitarie he was / and euere alloone
(base) And waillynge al the nyght . makynge his moone
(base) And if he herde / soong or Instrument
(base) Thanne wolde he wepe / he myghte nat be stent
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) So feble eek were his spiritz / and so lowe
(base) And chaunged so / that no man koude knowe
(base) His speche / nor his voys / thogh men it herde
(base) And in his gere / for al the world he ferde
(base) Nat oonly / lyk the loueris maladye
(base) Of Hereos / but rather lyk Manye
(base) Engendred / of humour malencolyk
(base) Biforn his Celle fantastyk
(base) And shortly / turned was / al vp so down
(base) Bothe habit and eek disposicioun
(base) Of hym / this woful louere daun Arcite
(base) ¶ What sholde I al day / of his wo endite
(base) Whanne he endured hadde / a yeer / or two
(base) This cruel torment and this peyne and wo
(base) At Thebes in his contree / as I seyde
(base) Vpon a nyght in sleep / as he hym leyde
(base) Hym thoughte / how that the wynged god Mercurye
(base) Biforn hym stood / and bad hym to be murye
(base) His slepy yerde / in honde he bar vprighte
(base) An hat he wered / vpon his herys brighte
(base) Arrayed was this god / as he took keep
(base) As he was / whan that Argus took his sleep
(base) And seyde hym thus / to Atthenes shaltow wende
(base) Ther is thee shapen / of thy wo an ende
(base) ¶ And with that word / Arcite wook and sterte
(base) Now trewely / how sore that me smerte
(base) Quod he / to Atthenes right now wol I fare
(base) Ne for the drede of deeth / shal I nat spare
(base) To se my lady / that I loue and serue
(base) In hir presence / I recche nat to sterue
(base) ¶ And with that word / he caughte a greet Mirour
(base) And saugh / that chaunged was al his colour
(base) And saugh his visage / al in another kynde
(base) And right anoon / it ran hym in his mynde
(base) That sith his face / was so disfigured
(base) Of maladie / the which he hadde endured
(base) He myghte wel / if that he bar hym lowe
(base) Lyue in Atthenes / eueremoore vnknowe
(base) And seen his lady / wel ny / day by day
(base) And right anoon / he chaunged his array
(base) And cladde hym / as a poure laborer
(base) And al allone / saue oonly a Squyer
(base) That knew his pryuetee / and al his cas
(base) Which was disgised / pourely as he was
(base) To Atthenes / is he goon / the nexte way
(base) And to the Court he wente vpon a day
(base) And at the gate / he profreth his seruyse
(base) To drugge and drawe / what so men wol deuyse
(base) ¶ And shortly / of this matere / for to seyn
(base) He fil in office / with a Chambreleyn
(base) The which / that dwellyng was wᵗith Emelye
(base) For he was wys / and koude soone espye
(base) Of euery seruant which that serueth here
(base) Wel koude he / hewen wode / and water bere
(base) For he was yong . and myghty for the nones
(base) And ther to / he was strong and byg of bones
(base) To doon / what any wight kan hym deuyse
(base) A yeer / or two / he was in this seruyse
(base) Page of the chambre / of Emelie the brighte
(base) And Philostrate / he seyde that he highte
(base) ¶ But half so wel biloued a man / as he
(base) Ne was ther neuere in Court of his degree
(base) He was so gentil / of condicioun
(base) That thurgh out al the Court was his renoun
(base) They seiden / that it were a charitee
(base) That Theseus / wolde enhauncen his degree
(base) And putten hym / in worshipful seruyse
(base) Ther as he myghte / his vertu excercise
(base) And thus with Inne a while / his name is spronge
(base) Bothe of his dedes / and his goode tonge
(base) That Theseus / hath taken hym so ner
(base) That of his chambre / he made hym a Squier
(base) And gaf hym gold / to mayntene his degree
(base) And eek men broghte hym / out of his contree
(base) Fro yeer to yeer / ful pryuely his rente
(base) But honestly / and sleighly / he it spente
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) That no man wondred / how that he it hadde
(base) And thre yeer in this wise / his lyf he ladde
(base) And bar hym so / in pees / and ek in werre
(base) Ther was no man / that Theseus hath derre
(base) And in this blisse / lete I now Arcite
(base) And speke I wole / of Palamon alite
(base) ¶ In derknesse / and horrible / and strong prisoun
(base) This seuen yeer / hath seten Palamoun
(base) Forpyned / what for wo / and for distresse
(base) Who feeleth / double soor / and heuynesse

(base) ¶ Estward ther stood a gate / of Marbul whit
(base) Westward / right swich another / in the oposit
(base) And shortly to concluden / swich a place
(base) Was noon in erthe / as in so lite a space
(base) For in the lond / ther was no crafty man
(base) That Geometrye / or Ars metrik kan
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Ne purtreyour / ne keruere of ymages
(base) That Theseus / ne yaf mete and wages
(base) The Theatre / for to maken and deuyse
(base) And for to doon / his ryte and sacrifise
(base) He Estward hath / vpon the gate aboue
(base) In worship of venus / goddesse of loue
(base) Doon maad an Auter / and an oratorie
(base) And on the westward / in memorie
(base) Of Mars / he maked hath right swich another
(base) That coste largely / of gold a fother
(base) And Northward / in a touret on the wal
(base) Of Alabastre whit and reed Coral
(base) An oratorie / riche for to see
(base) In worship / of Diane of chastitee
(base) Hath Theseus / doon wroght in noble wise
(base) ¶ But yet hadde I forgeten / to deuyse
(base) The noble keruyng and the purtreitures
(base) The shap / the contenance / and the figures
(base) That weren / in thise oratories thre
(base) ¶ First / in the temple of Venus / mayst thow se
(base) Wroght on the wal / ful pitous to biholde
(base) The broken slepes / and the sykes colde
(base) The sacred teerys / and the waymentynge
(base) The firy strokes / of the desirynge
(base) That loues seruantz / in this lyf enduren
(base) The othes / that hir couenantz assuren
(base) Plesance / and hope / desir / foolhardynesse
(base) Beautee and youthe / baudrye / richesse
(base) Charmes and force / lesynges / flaterye
(base) Despense / bisynesse / and Ialousye
(base) That wered / of yelowe gooldes a gerland
(base) And a Cokkow / sittyng on hir hand
(base) Festes / Instrumentz / caroles / daunces
(base) Lust and array / and alle the circumstaunces
(base) Of loue / whiche that I rekned / and rekne shal
(base) By ordre / weren peynted on the wal
(base) And mo / than I kan make of mencioun
(base) For soothly / al the Mount of Citheroun
(base) Ther Venus / hath hir principal dwellynge
(base) Was shewed on the wal / in purtreyynge
(base) With al the gardyn / and the lustynesse
(base) Nat was foryeten / the porter ydelnesse
(base) Ne Narcisus the faire / of yoore agon
(base) Ne yet the folie / of kyng Salomon
(base) The enchauntement of medea and hardynesse
(base) Of Iason I wil not now expresse
(base) Ne yet the grete strengthe of Ercules
(base) The enchantementz / of Medea and Circes
(base) Ne of Turnus / with the hardy fiers corage
(base) The ryche Cresus / caytif in seruage
(base) ¶ Thus may ye seen / that wisdom ne richesse
(base) Beautee / ne sleighte / strengthe hardynesse
(base) Ne may with venus / maken champartie
(base) For as hir lust the world than may she gye
(base) Lo al this folk so caught were in hir laas
(base) Til they for wo / ful ofte seyde allas
(base) Suffiseth heere ensamples / oon or two
(base) And though / I koude rekne a thousand mo
(base) ¶ The statue of Venus / glorious for to see
(base) Was naked / fletyng in the large See
(base) And fro the nauele doun / al couered was
(base) With wawes grene / and brighte as any glas
(base) A Citole in hir right hand / hadde she
(base) And on hir heed / ful semely for to se
(base) A rose gerland / fressh / and wel smellynge
(base) Aboue hir heed / hir dowues flikerynge
(base) Biforn hire stood / hir sone Cupido
(base) Vpon his shuldres / wynges hadde he two
(base) And blynd he was / as it is ofte seen
(base) A bowe he bar / and Arwes brighte and keene
(base) ¶ Why sholde I nat as wel / eek telle yow al
(base) The purtreyture / that was vpon the wal
(base) With Inne the temple / of myghty Mars the rede
(base) Al peynted was the wal / in lengthe and brede
(base) Lyk to the eestres / of the grisly place
(base) That highte the grete temple / of Mars in Trace
(base) In thilke colde / frosty Regioun
(base) Ther as Mars / hath his souereyn mansioun
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) ¶ First on the wal / was peynted a Forest
(base) In which ther dwelleth / neither man ne best
(base) With knotty / knarry / bareyne trees olde
(base) Of stubbes sharpe / and hidouse to biholde
(base) In which / ther ran a rombul / in a swough
(base) As thogh a storm / sholde bresten euery bough
(base) And downward on an hil / vnder a bente
(base) Ther stood the temple / of Mars Armypotente
(base) Wroght al of burned steel / of which the entree
(base) Was long and streyt and gastly for to see
(base) And ther out cam a rage / and swich a veze
(base) That it made / al the gate for to rese
(base) The Northren light in at the dores shoon
(base) For wyndow on the wal / ne was ther noon
(base) Thurgh which men myghten / any light discerne
(base) The dore was al / of Athamant eterne
(base) Yclenched / ouerthwart and endelong /
(base) With Iren togh / and for to make it strong
(base) Euery piler / the temple to sustene
(base) Was tonne greet of Iren bright and shene
(base) ¶ Ther say I first. the dirke ymagynynge
(base) Of felonye / and al the compassynge
(base) The cruel Ire / reed as any gleede
(base) The pike purs / and eek the pale drede
(base) The smylere / with the knyf vnder the cloke
(base) The shipne brennyng with the blake smoke
(base) The tresoun / of the mordryng in the bed
(base) The open werre / with woundes al bibled
(base) Contek with blody knyf and sharp manace
(base) Al ful of chirkyng was that sory place
(base) ¶ The sleere of hymself / yet saugh I ther
(base) His herte blood / hath bathed al his heer
(base) The nayl ydryuen / in the shode a nyght
(base) The colde deeth / with mouth gapyng vp right
(base) Amyddes of the temple / sat meschaunce
(base) With disconfort and sory contenaunce
(base) ¶ Yet saugh I woodnesse / laughyng in his rage
(base) Armed compleynt out hees / and fiers outrage
(base) The caroyne in the bussh / with throte ycorue
(base) A thousand slayn / and noght of qualm ystorue
(base) The tiraunt with the praye / by force yraft
(base) The town destroyed / ther was no thyng laft
(base) ¶ Yet saugh I brent. the shippes hoppesteres
(base) The hunte strangled / with the wilde beres
(base) The hunt strangled with wilde bores corage
(base) The Sowe freten the child / right in the Cradel
(base) The Cook yscalded / for al his longe ladel
(base) ¶ Naught was forgeten / by the Infortune of Marte
(base) The Cartere / ouer ryden / with his Carte
(base) Vnder the wheel / ful lowe he lay adown
(base) Ther were also / of Martes deuysioun
(base) The Barbour / and the Bochier and the Smyth
(base) That forgeth sharpe swerdes / on his styth
(base) ¶ And al aboue / depeynted in a tour
(base) Saugh I Conquest sittyng in greet honour
(base) With the sharpe swerd / ouer his heed
(base) Hangynge / by a subtil twynes threed
(base) ¶ Depeynted was / the slaghtre of Iulius
(base) Of grete Nero / and of Anthonius
(base) Al be / that thilke tyme / they were vnborn
(base) Yet was hir deeth / depeynted ther biforn
(base) By manacynge of Mars / right by figure
(base) So was it shewed / in that purtreyture
(base) As is depeynted / in the Sertres aboue
(base) Who shal be slayn / or ellis deed for loue
(base) Suffiseth oon ensample / in stories olde
(base) I may nat rekne hem alle / thogh I wolde
(base) ¶ The Statue of Mars / vpon a Carte stood
(base) Lyke vnto the figure of vigynys
(base) Armed / and loked grym / as he were wood
(base) And ouer his heed / ther shynen two figures
(base) Of sterres / that been clepyd in Scriptures
(base) That oon Puella / that oother Rubeus
(base) This god of armes / was arrayed thus
(base) A wolf ther stood / bifore hym at his feet
(base) With eyen rede / and of a man he eet
(base) With subtil pencel / was depeynted this storie
(base) In redoutynge of Mars / and of his glorie
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) ¶ Now to the temple / of Diane the chaste
(base) As shortly as I kan / I wol me haste
(base) To telle yow / al the discripsioun
(base) Depeynted been the walles / vp and doun
(base) Of huntyng and of shamefast chastitee
(base) Ther saw I. / how woful Calistopee
(base) Whan that Diane / agreued was with here
(base) Was turned / fro a womman / til a Bere
(base) And after was she maad / the lode sterre
(base) Thus was it peynted / I kan seye yow no ferre
(base) That shynyth in the hevy / frōm yow so ferre
(base) Hir sone is eek a sterre / as men may see
(base) Ther saw I Dane / yturned to a tree
(base) I mene nat / the goddesse Diane
(base) But Penneus doghter / which that highte Dane
(base) ¶ Ther saw I Attheon / an hert ymaked
(base) For vengeaunce / that he saw Diane al naked
(base) I seigh / how that hise houndes haue hym caught
(base) And freten hym / for that they knewe hym naught
(base) ¶ Yet peynted was / a litel ferther moor
(base) How Atthalante / hunted the wilde boor
(base) And Meleagree / and many another mo
(base) For which Diane / wroghte hym care and wo
(base) Ther saw I. many another wonder storie
(base) The whiche / me list nat drawen to memorie
(base) ¶ This goddesse on hert ful hye seet
(base) With smale houndes / al aboute hir feet
(base) And vnder nethe hir feet. she hadde a moone
(base) Wexinge it was / and sholde wanye soone
(base) In gaude grene / hir statue yclothed was
(base) With bowe in honde / and arwes in a cas
(base) Hir eyen caste she / ful lowe adown
(base) Ther Pluto / hath his dirke Regioun
(base) A womman trauailyng was hir biforn
(base) But for hir child / so longe was vnborn
(base) Ful pitously / lucina gan she calle
(base) And seyde help / for thow mayst best of alle
(base) Wel koude he peynte lyfly / that it wroghte
(base) With many a floryn / he the hewes boghte
(base) ¶ Now been thise listes maad / and Theseus
(base) That at his grete cost arrayed thus
(base) The temples / and the Theatre euery del
(base) Whan it was doon / hym liked wonder wel
(base) But stynte I wole / of Theseus alite
(base) And speke of Palamon / and of Arcite
(base) ¶ The day approcheth / of hir retournynge
(base) That euerich / sholde an hundred knyghtes brynge
(base) The bataille to darreyne / as I yow tolde
(base) And til Atthenes / hir couenant for to holde
(base) Hath euerich of hem / broght a hundred knyghtes
(base) Wel armed for the werre / at alle rightes
(base) And sikerly / ther trowed many a man
(base) That neuere sithen / that the world bigan
(base) As for to speke / of knyghthod of hir hond
(base) As fer / as god hath maked see and lond
(base) Nas of so fewe / so noble a compaignye
(base) For euery wight that loued chiualrye
(base) And wolde his thankes / han a passant name
(base) Hath prayd / that he myghte been of that game
(base) And wel was hym / that ther to chosen was
(base) For if ther fille / tomorwe swich a cas
(base) Ye knowen wel / that euery lusty knyght /
(base) That loueth paramours / and hath his myght
(base) Were it in Engelond / or ellis where
(base) They wolde hir thankes / wilnen to be there
(base) To fighten for a lady / benedicitee
(base) It were a lusty sighte / for to see
(base) ¶ And right so / ferden they with Palamon
(base) With hym ther wenten / knyghtes many oon
(base) Som wol ben armed / in an haubergeoun
(base) And in a Brestplate / and in a light gypoun
(base) And som wol haue / a peire plates large
(base) And some willen haue a pruce schelde othir targe
(base) And som wol haue / a Pruce sheeld / or a targe
(base) Som wol been armed / on his legges weel
(base) And haue an Ax / and som a Maas of steel
(base) Ther nys no newe gyse / that it nas oold
(base) Armed were they / as I haue yow toold
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Euerich / after his opinyoun
(base) ¶ Ther maystow seen / comynge with Palamoun
(base) Lygurge hymself the grete kyng of Trace
(base) Blak was his beerd / and manly was his face
(base) The cercles of his eyen / in his heed
(base) They gloweden / bitwixen yelow and reed
(base) And lyk a griffoun / loked he aboute
(base) With keempe herys / on his browes stoute
(base) His lymes grete / his brawnes / harde and stronge
(base) Hys shuldres brode / hise armes rounde and longe
(base) And as the gyse was / in his contree
(base) Ful hye / vpon a Chaar of gold stood he
(base) With foure white Boles / in the trays
(base) In stide of Cotearmure / ouer his harnays
(base) With nayles yelwe / and brighte as any gold
(base) He hadde a Berys Skyn / colblak / for old
(base) His longe heer / was kembed bihynde his bak
(base) As any Rauenes fethere / it shoon for blak
(base) A wrethe of gold / greet of huge wighte
(base) Vpon his heed / and ful of stones brighte
(base) Of fyne Rubyes / and of dyamauntz
(base) Aboute his Chaar / ther wente white Alauntz
(base) Twenty and mo / as grete as any steer
(base) To hunten at the leoun / and the deer
(base) And folwed hym / with mosel faste ybounde
(base) Colered of gold / and turrettes filed rounde
(base) An hundred lordes / hadde he in his route
(base) Armed ful wel / with hertes stierne and stoute
(base) ¶ With Arcita / in stories as men fynde
(base) The grete Emetrius / the kyng of Inde
(base) Vpon a Steede bay / trapped in steel
(base) Couered in a clooth of gold / dyapred weel
(base) Cam ridynge / lyk the god of Armes Mars
(base) His cote armure / was of clooth of Tars
(base) Couched with perlys white / and rounde and grete
(base) His sadel was / of brend gold newe ybete
(base) A Mantelet vpon his shulder hangynge
(base) Bretful of Rubies reede / as fyr sparklynge
(base) His crispe heer / lyk rynges was yronne
(base) And that was yelow / and glitred as the sonne
(base) His nose was heigh / hise eyen bright Citryn
(base) His lyppes rounde / his colour was sangwyn
(base) A fewe fraknes / in his face yspreynd
(base) Bitwixen yelow / and som del blak ymeynd
(base) And as a leoun / he his lookyng caste
(base) Of . xxv. yeer / his age I caste
(base) His beerd / was wel bigonne for to sprynge
(base) His voys / was as a trompe thonderynge
(base) Vpon his heed / he wered of laurer grene
(base) A gerland fressh / and lusty for to seene
(base) Vpon his hand / he bar for his deduyt
(base) An Egle tame / as any lilie whyt
(base) An hundred lordes / hadde he with hym there
(base) Al armed saue hir heddes / in al hir gere
(base) Ful richely / in alle manere thynges
(base) For trusteth wel / that dukes / Erles / kynges
(base) Were gadred / in this noble compaignye
(base) For loue / and for encrees of chiualrye
(base) Aboute this kyng ther ran on euery part
(base) Ful many a tame leoun and leopart
(base) ¶ And in this wise / thise lordes alle and some
(base) Been on the Sonday / to the Citee come
(base) Aboute pryme / and in the town alight
(base) ¶ This Theseus / this duc this worthy knyght
(base) Whan he hadde broght hem / in to his Citee
(base) And Inned hem / euerich at his degree
(base) He festeth hem / and dooth so gret labour
(base) To esen hem / and doon hem al honour
(base) That yet men wenen / that no mannes wit
(base) Of noon estaat ne koude amenden it /
(base) ¶ The Mynstralcye / the seruyce / at the feeste
(base) The grete yiftes / to the meeste and leeste
(base) The ryche array / of Theseus Paleys
(base) Ne who sat first or last vpon the deys
(base) What ladyes fairest been / and best daunsynge
(base) Or which of hem / kan daunse best and synge
(base) Ne who moost feelyngly / speketh of loue
(base) What haukes sitten / on the perche aboue
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) What houndes lyggen / on the floor adown
(base) Of al this / make I now no mencioun
(base) But al theffect that thynketh me the beste
(base) Now comth the point and herkneth if yow leste
(base) ¶ The Sonday nyght er day bigan to sprynge
(base) Whan Palamon / the larke herde synge
(base) Althogh it nere nat day / by houres two
(base) Yet soong the larke / and Palamon right tho
(base) Vnto the temple purposeth he to go
(base) With holy herte / and with an heigh corage
(base) He roos / to wenden on his pilgrymage
(base) Vnto the blisful / Scitherea benygne
(base) I mene Venus / honurable and digne
(base) And in hir hour / he walketh forth a paas
(base) Vnto the lystes / ther hir temple was
(base) And down he kneleth / and with humble cheere
(base) And herte soor / he seyde as ye shal heere
(base) ¶ Faireste of faire / o lady myn Venus
(base) Doghter of Ioue / and spouse to Vulcanus
(base) Thow gladere / of the mount of Cytheron
(base) For thilke loue / thow haddest to Adoon
(base) Haue pitee / of my bittre teerys smerte
(base) And taak myn humble prayere at thyn herte
(base) ¶ Allas I ne haue no langage to telle
(base) Theffect. ne the tormentz of myn helle
(base) Myn herte / may myne harmes nat biwreye
(base) I am so confus / that I kan noght seye
(base) But mercy lady bright that knowest wele
(base) My thoght and seest what harmes that I feele
(base) Considre al this / and rewe vpon my soore
(base) As wisly / as I shal for euere moore
(base) Emforth my myght thy trewe seruant be
(base) And holden werre / alwey with chastitee
(base) That make I myn avow / so ye me helpe
(base) I kepe noght of armes for to yelpe
(base) Ne I ne axe noght to morwe / to haue victorie
(base) Ne renoun in this cas / ne veyne glorie
(base) Of prys of armes / blowen vp and down
(base) But I wolde haue / fully possessioun
(base) Of Emelye / and dye in thy seruyse
(base) Fynd thow the manere / how / and in what wyse
(base) I recche nat but it may bettre be
(base) To haue victorie of hem / or they of me
(base) So that I haue / my lady in myn armes
(base) For thogh so be / that Mars is god of armes
(base) Youre vertu is so greet in heuene aboue
(base) That if yow list I shal wel haue my loue
(base) ¶ Thy temple / wol I worshipe eueremo
(base) And on thyn Auter / wher I ryde or go
(base) I wol doon sacrifice / and fyres beete
(base) And if ye wol noght so / my lady sweete
(base) Thanne praye I thee / to morwe with a spere
(base) That Arcita / me thurgh the herte bere
(base) Thanne rekke I noght whan I haue lost my lyf
(base) Thogh that Arcita / wynne hire to his wyf
(base) This is theffect and ende of my prayere
(base) Yif me my loue / thow blisful lady deere
(base) ¶ Whan the orison was doon / of Palamon
(base) His sacrifice he dide / and that anon
(base) Ful pitously / with alle circumstances
(base) Al telle I nat as now / his obseruances
(base) But at the laste / the Statue of Venus shook
(base) And made a signe / wher by that he took
(base) That his prayere / accepted was that day
(base) For thogh the signe / shewed a delay
(base) Yet wiste he wel / that graunted was his boone
(base) And with glad herte / he wente hym hoom ful soone
(base) ¶ The thridde hour in equal / that Palamon
(base) Bigan / to Venus temple / for to gon
(base) Vp roos the sonne / and vp roos Emelye
(base) And to the temple of Diane / gan hye
(base) Hir maydens / that she thider with hire ladde
(base) Ful redily with hem / the fyr they hadde
(base) Thencens / the clothes / and the remenant al
(base) That to the sacrifice / longen shal
(base) The hornes ful of Mede / as was the gyse
(base) Ther lakked noght to doon hir sacrifise
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) ¶ Smokynge the temple / ful of clothes faire
(base) This Emelye / with herte debonaire
(base) Hir body wessh / with water of a welle
(base) Hire body wesshe with herte debonarie
(base) But hou she dide hir ryte / I dar nat telle
(base) But it be / any thyng in general
(base) And yet it were a game / to heren al
(base) To hym that meneth wel / it nere no charge
(base) But it is good / a man be at his large
(base) ¶ Hir brighte heer was kembed / vntressed al
(base) A corone / of a grene ook cerial
(base) Vpon hir heed was set ful fair and meete
(base) Two fyres / on the Auter gan she beete
(base) And dide hir thynges / as men may biholde
(base) In Stace of Thebes / and othere bokes olde
(base) Whan kyndled was the fyr / with pitous cheere
(base) Vnto Diane / she spak / as ye may heere
(base) ¶ O chaste goddesse / of the wodes grene
(base) To whom / bothe heuene / and erthe / and See is seene
(base) Queene of the regne of Pluto / derk and lowe
(base) Goddesse of maydens / that myn herte hast knowe
(base) Ful many a yeer / and woost what I desire
(base) As keep me / fro thy vengeance and thyn Ire
(base) That Attheoun / aboghte crewelly
(base) Chaste goddesse / wel wostow that I
(base) Desire / to been a mayden / al my lyf
(base) Ne neuere wol I be / no loue / ne wyf
(base) I am thow woost yet of thy compaignye
(base) A mayde / and loue huntyng and venerye
(base) And for to walken / in the wodes wilde
(base) And noght to been a wyf / and be with childe
(base) Noght wol I knowe / compaignye of man
(base) Now help me lady / sith ye may and kan
(base) For tho thre formes / that thow hast in thee
(base) And Palamon / that hath swich loue to me
(base) And eek Arcite / that loueth me so soore
(base) This grace I praye thee / withoute moore
(base) As seend loue and pees / bitwix hem two
(base) And fro me / turn awey / hir hertes so
(base) That al hir hote loue / and hir desir
(base) And al hir bisy torment and hir fyr
(base) Be queynt and turned in another place
(base) And if so be / thow wolt noght do me grace
(base) Or if my destynee / be shape so
(base) That I shal nedes / haue oon of hem two
(base) As seend me hym / that moost desireth me
(base) Bihoold goddesse / of clene chastitee
(base) The bittre teerys / that on my chekes falle
(base) Syn thow art mayde / and kepere of vs alle
(base) My maydenhode thow kepe / and wel conserue
(base) And whil I lyue / a mayde I wol thee serue
(base) ¶ The fyres brenne / vpon the Auter cleere
(base) Whil Emelie / is thus in hir prayere
(base) But sodeynly / she seigh a sighte queynte

(base) ¶ Nat may the woful spirit in myn herte
(base) Declare a point of alle my sorwes smerte
(base) To yow my lady / that I loue moost
(base) But I byquethe / the seruice of my goost
(base) To yow / abouen euery creature
(base) Syn that my lyf / may no lenger dure
(base) Allas the wo / allas the peynes stronge
(base) That I for yow haue suffred / and so longe
(base) Allas the deeth / allas myn Emelye
(base) Allas / departyng of oure compaignye
(base) Allas myn hertes queene / allas my wif
(base) Myn hertes lady / endere of my lyf
(base) Myn hertys lady cawser of my tene
(base) What is this world / what axeth men to haue
(base) Now with his loue / now in his colde graue
(base) Allone / with outen any compaignye
(base) Fare wel / my sweete foo / myn Emelye
(base) And softe taak me / in youre Armes tweye
(base) For loue of god / and herkneth what I seye
(base) ¶ I haue heer / with my cosyn Palamoun
(base) Had stryf and rancour / many a day goun
(base) For loue of yow / and for my Ialousye
(base) And Iuppiter / so wys my soule gye
(base) To speken / of a seruaunt proprely
(base) With circumstaunces alle / trewely
(base) That is to seyn / trouthe / honour / knyghthede
(base) Wisdom / humblesse / estaat / and heigh kynrede
(base) Fredom / and al / that longeth to that art
(base) So Iuppiter / haue of my soule part
(base) As in this world / right now ne knowe I non
(base) So worthy to been loued / as Palamon
(base) That serueth yow / and wol doon al his lyf
(base) And if that euere / ye shal been a wyf
(base) Foryet nat Palamon / the gentil man
(base) And with that word / his speche faille gan
(base) For from his feet vp to his brest was come
(base) The coold of deeth / that hadde hym ouercome
(base) And yet moore ouer / for in his armes two
(base) The vital strengthe / is lost and al ago
(base) Oonly the Intellect withoute moore
(base) That dwelled in his herte / syk and soore
(base) Gan faillen / whan the herte felte deeth
(base) Dusked hise eyen two / and fayled breeth
(base) But on his lady / yet caste he his eye
(base) His laste word / was mercy Emelye
(base) His spirit chaunged hous / and wente ther
(base) As I cam neuere / I kan nat tellen wher
(base) Therfore I stynte / I nam no dyuynystre
(base) Of soules / fynde I nat in this Registre
(base) Ne me ne lyst / thilke opynyons to telle
(base) Of hem / thogh that they writen wher they dwelle
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Arcite is coold / ther Mars his soule gye
(base) Now wol I speken / forth of Emelye
(base) That soroweth and cryeth I wyl not lye
(base) Now wepith Emelye ⁊and waylith Palamon
(base) ¶ Shrighte Emelye / and howleth Palamon
(base) And Theseus / his suster took anon
(base) Swownynge / and baar hire fro the corps away
(base) What helpeth it to tarien forth the day
(base) To tellen how she weep / bothe eue and morwe
(base) For in swich caas / wommen haue swich sorwe
(base) Whan that hir housbondes / been from hem ago
(base) That for the moore part they sorwen so
(base) Or ellis fallen / in swich a maladye
(base) That at the laste / certeinly they dye
(base) ¶ Infinite / been the sorwes and the teerys
(base) Of olde folk. and folk of tendre yeerys
(base) In al the town / for the deeth of this Theban
(base) As þat þ̉er/re was for deþ of þis Theban
(base) For hym ther wepeth bothe child a man
(base) For sorwe of him þer weepeþ boþe child and man
(base) So greet wepyng was ther noon certayn
(base) Whan Ector was broght al fressh yslayn
(base) To Troye / allas the pitee that was ther
(base) Cracchynge of chekes / rentyng eek of heer
(base) Why woldest thow be deed / thise wommen crye
(base) And haddest gold ynow / and Emelye
(base) ¶ No man / myghte gladen Theseus
(base) Sauyng his olde fader Egeus
(base) That knew / this worldes transmutacioun
(base) As he hadde seyn it chaungen / bothe vp and down
(base) Ioye after wo / and wo after gladnesse
(base) And shewed hem / ensample and lyknesse
(base) ¶ Right as ther deyed neuere man / quod he
(base) That he ne lyued in erthe / in som degree
(base) Right so / ther lyued neuere man he seyde
(base) In al this world / that som tyme he ne deyde
(base) This world / nys but a thurghfare / ful of wo
(base) And we been pilgrymes / passynge to and fro
(base) Deeth is an ende / of euery worldly soore
(base) And oueral this / yet seyde he muchel moore
(base) To this effect ful wysly / to enhorte
(base) The peple / that they sholde hem reconforte
(base) ¶ Duc Theseus / withal his bisy cure
(base) Caste now / wher that the sepulture
(base) Of goode Arcite / may best ymaked be
(base) And eek moost honurable / in his degree
(base) And at the laste / he took conclusioun
(base) That ther / as first Arcite and Palamoun
(base) Hadden for loue / the bataille hem bitwene
(base) That in the selue groue / swoote and grene
(base) Ther as he hadde / hise amorouse desires
(base) His compleinte / and for loue his hote fyres
(base) He wolde make a fyr / in which the office
(base) Funeral / he myghte al acomplice
(base) And leet anoon comaunde / to hakke and hewe
(base) The okes olde / and leyen hem on a rewe
(base) In colpons / wel arrayed for to brenne
(base) Hise officers / with swifte feet they renne
(base) And ryde anoon / at his comandement
(base) And after this / Theseus hath ysent
(base) After a Beere / and it al ouerspradde
(base) With clooth of gold / the richeste / that he hadde
(base) And of the same suyte / he cladde Arcite
(base) Vpon his handes / his gloues white
(base) Eek on his heed / a coroune of laurer greene
(base) And in his hand / a swerd ful bright and keene
(base) He leyde hym bare the visage / on the beere
(base) Ther with he weep / that pitee was to heere
(base) And for the peple / sholde seen hym alle
(base) Whan it was day / he broghte hym to the halle
(base) That roreth / of the cryyng and the sown
(base) Tho cam / this woful Theban Palamoun
(base) With flotry berd / and ruggy asshy heerys
(base) In clothes blake / ydropped al with teerys
(base) And passyng othere / of wepyng Emelye
(base) The rufulleste / of al the compaignye
(base) In as muche / as the seruyce sholde be
(base) The moore noble / and ryche in his degree
(base) Duc Theseus / leet forth thre steedes brynge
(base) ¶ Duke theseus anon with oute lette
(base) Thre stedis white hath comaundid sette
(base) Vpon the whiche stedes trapped welle
(base) With cloth of golde ouer maile of stel
(base) That trapped weren in steel al gliterynge
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) And couered with the armes / of daun Arcite
(base) Vpon thise steedes / grete and whyte
(base) Ther seten folk / of which oon baar his sheeld
(base) Another his spere / vpon his hondes heeld
(base) The thridde bar with hym / his bowe Turkeys
(base) Of brend gold / was the caas / and eek the harneys
(base) And ryden forth a paas / with sorweful cheere
(base) Toward the groue / as ye shul after heere
(base) The nobleste of the Grekys / that ther were
(base) Vpon hir shuldres / carieden the beere
(base) With slak paas / and eyen rede and weete
(base) Thurgh out the Citee / by the maister streete
(base) That sprad was al with blak and wonder hye
(base) Right of the same / is the strete ywrye
(base) Vpon the right hand / wente olde Egeus
(base) And on that oother syde / duc Theseus
(base) With vessels in hir hand / of gold ful fyn
(base) Al ful of hony / melk / and blood and wyn
(base) Eek Palamon / with ful greet compaignye
(base) And after that / cam woful Emelye
(base) With fyr in hande / as was that tyme the gyse
(base) To do the office / of funeral seruyse
(base) ¶ Heigh labour / and greet apparaillynge
(base) Was at the seruyce / and the fyr makynge
(base) That with his grene top / the heuene raughte
(base) And twenty fadme of brede / the armes straughte
(base) This is to seyn / the bowes / were so brode
(base) Of stree first ther was leyd many a lode
(base) But how the fyr was maked vpon highte
(base) Ne eek the names / how the trees highte
(base) As ook / Fyrre / Birch / Asp / Alder / holm / popler
(base) Wylow / Elm / Plane / Assh / Box / Chestayn / lynde / laurer
(base) Wilow / elme / plane hasil and whipultre
(base) Mapul / Thorn / Beech / hasyl / Ew / whippultree
(base) Mapil thorn / bech / aspe / box chesteyn lynd / laurer
(base) How they were feld / shal nat been told for me
(base) Ne how the goddes / ronnen vp and doun
(base) Desherited / of hir habitacioun
(base) In which they woneden / in reste and pees
(base) Nymphes / Fawnes / and Amadrides
(base) Ne how the beestes / and the bryddes alle
(base) Fledden / for fered / whan the wode was falle
(base) Ne how the ground / agast was of the lyght
(base) That was nat wont to seen the sonne bright
(base) Ne how the fyr / was couched first with stree
(base) And thanne with drye stikkes / clouen a three
(base) And thanne with grene wode / and spicerye
(base) And thanne with clooth of gold / and with perrye
(base) And thanne with cloth of golde and with perie
(base) And gerlandes hangynge / ful of many a flour
(base) The Mirre / thencens / withal so greet sauour
(base) Ne how Arcite / lay among al this
(base) Ne what richesse / aboute the body is
(base) Ne how that Emelye / as was the gyse
(base) Putte in the fyr / of funeral seruyse
(base) Ne how she swowned / whan men made the fyr
(base) Ne what she spak ne what was hir desir
(base) Ne what Iuels / men in the fyr caste
(base) Whan that the fyr was greet and brente faste
(base) Ne how somme caste hir sheeld / and somme hir spere
(base) And of hir vestimentz / whiche that they were
(base) And coppes fulle of Milk and wyn and blood
(base) In to the fyr / that brente as it were wood
(base) Ne how the Grekys / with An huge route
(base) Thries ryden / al the fyr aboute
(base) Vpon the left hand / with a loud shoutynge
(base) And thries / with hir speres claterynge
(base) And thryes wᵗith here sperys claterynge
(base) And thries / how the ladyes gonne crye
(base) And how that lad / was homward Emelye
(base) Ne how Arcite / is brent to Asshen colde
(base) Ne how that lychwake / was yholde
(base) Al thilke nyght ne how the grekys pleye
(base) The wake pleyes / ne kepe I noght to seye
(base) Who wrastleth best naked / with oille enoynt
(base) Ne who that baar hym best in no disioynt
(base) I wol nat tellen al / how they goon
(base) Hoom til Atthenes / whan the pleye is doon
(base) But shortly to the poynt than wol I wende
(base) And maken / of my longe tale an ende
(base) ¶ By proces / and by lengthe of certeyn yerys
(base) Al stynt is / the moornynge and the terys
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Of Grekys / by oon general assent
(base) Thanne semed me / ther was a parlement
(base) At Atthenes / vpon a certeyn point and caas
(base) Among the whiche pointes / yspoken was
(base) To haue / with certeyn contrees alliance
(base) And haue fully / of Thebans obeisance
(base) For which / this noble Theseus anon
(base) Leet senden / after gentil Palamon
(base) Vnwist of hym / what was the cause and why
(base) But in his blake clothes / sorwefully
(base) He cam at his comandement / in hye
(base) Tho sente Theseus / for Emelye
(base) ¶ Whan they were set and hust was al the place
(base) And Theseus / abiden hath a space
(base) Er any word / cam from his wise brest /
(base) His eyen sette he / ther as was his lest
(base) And with a sad visage / he siked stille
(base) And after that right thus he seyde his wille
(base) ¶ The firste moeuere / of the cause aboue
(base) Whan he first made / the faire cheyne of loue
(base) Greet was theffect and heigh was his entente
(base) Wel wiste he why / and what ther of he mente
(base) For with that faire cheyne of loue he boond
(base) The fyr the Eyr / the water / and the loond
(base) In certeyn boundes / that they may nat flee
(base) That same Prince / and that moeuere quod he
(base) Hath stabliced / in this wrecched world adoun
(base) Certeine dayes / and duracioun
(base) To al / that is engendred / in this place
(base) Ouer the which day / they may nat pace
(base) Al mowe they yet / tho dayes abregge
(base) Ther nedeth / noon auctoritee to allegge
(base) For it is proued / by experience
(base) But that me list declaren my sentence
(base) Thanne may men wel / by this ordre discerne
(base) That thilke moeuere / stable is and eterne
(base) Wel may men knowe / but it be a fool
(base) That euery part. is diryued from his hool
(base) For nature / hath nat taken his bigynnyng
(base) Of no partie / or of cantel of a thyng
(base) But of a thyng. that parfit is and stable
(base) Descendynge so / til it be corrumpable
(base) And therfore / for his wise purueiaunce
(base) He hath / so wel biset his ordinaunce
(base) That specis of thynges / and progressions
(base) Shullen enduren / by successions
(base) And noght eterne / withouten any lye
(base) This maist thow vnderstonde / and seen at Iye
(base) ¶ Loo the ook / that hath so long a norisshynge
(base) Fro the tyme / that it first gynneth sprynge
(base) And hath so long a lyf / as ye may see
(base) Yet at the laste / wasted is the tree
(base) ¶ Considreth eek / how that the harde stoon
(base) Vnder oure foot on which we ryde and goon
(base) It wasteth / as it lyth by the weye
(base) The brode Ryuer / som tyme wexeth dreye
(base) The grete townes / se we wane and wende
(base) Thanne se ye / that al this thyng hath ende
(base) Of man and womman / se we wel also
(base) That nedeth / in oon of thise termes two
(base) This is to seyn / in youthe / or ellis age
(base) He moot be deed / the kyng as shal a page
(base) Som in his bed / som in the depe see
(base) Som in the large feeld / as ye may se
(base) Ther helpeth noght al gooth that ilke weye
(base) Thanne may I seyn / that al this thyng moot deye
(base) What maketh this but Iuppiter the kyng
(base) That is Prince / and cause of alle thyng
(base) Conuertyng al vnto his propre welle
(base) From which it is diryued sooth to telle
(base) And heer agayns / no creature on lyue
(base) Of no degree / auailleth for to stryue
(base) ¶ Thanne is it wisdom / as it thynketh me
(base) To maken vertu / of necessitee
(base) And take it wel / that we may nat eschue
(base) And nameliche / that to vs alle is due
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) And who so gruccheth oght he dooth folye
(base) And rebel is / to hym that al may gye
(base) And certeinly / a man hath moost honour
(base) To dyen / in his excellence and flour
(base) Whan he is siker / of his goode name
(base) Thanne hath he doon / his freend ne hym no shame
(base) And gladder oghte / his freend been of his deeth
(base) Whan with honour / yolden is vp his breeth
(base) Than whan his name / apalled is for age
(base) For al forgeten is his vasselage
(base) Thanne is it best as for a worthy fame
(base) To dyen / whan he is best of name
(base) ¶ The contrarie of al this / is wilfulnesse
(base) Why grucchen we / why haue we heuynesse
(base) That goode Arcite / of chiualrie flour
(base) Departed is / with duetee / and with honour
(base) Out of this foule prison / of this lyf
(base) Why gruccheth heere / his cosyn and his wyf /
(base) Of his welfare / that loueth hem so weel
(base) Kan he hem thank nay god woot neuer a deel
(base) That bothe his soule / and eek hem self offende
(base) And yet they mowe / hir lustes nat amende
(base) ¶ What may I conclude / of this longe serye
(base) But after wo / I rede vs to be merye
(base) And thanken Iuppiter / of al his grace
(base) And er we / departen from this place
(base) I rede we make / of sorwes two
(base) O parfit Ioye / lastynge euere mo
(base) And loketh now / wher moost sorwe is her Inne
(base) Ther wol I first amenden and bigynne
(base) ¶ Suster quod he / this is my ful assent
(base) With al thauys / heer of my parlement
(base) That gentil Palamon / youre owene knyght
(base) That serueth yow / with wyl and herte myght
(base) And euere hath doon / syn ye first hym knewe
(base) That ye shal of youre grace vpon hym rewe
(base) And taken hym / for housbond and for lord
(base) Leen me youre hond / for this is oure acord
(base) Lat se now / of youre wommanly pitee
(base) He is / a kynges brother sone pardee
(base) And thogh he were / a poure Bachiler
(base) Syn he hath serued yow / so many a yeer
(base) And had for yow / so greet aduersitee
(base) It moste been considred / leueth me
(base) For gentil mercy / oghte to passen right
(base) ¶ Thanne seyde he thus / to Palamon the knyght
(base) I trowe / ther nedeth litel sermonyng
(base) To make yow / assente to this thyng
(base) Com neer / and taketh youre lady by the hond
(base) Bitwixe hem / was maad anon the bond
(base) That highte matrymoigne / or mariage
(base) By al the conseil / and the Baronage
(base) And thus / with alle blisse / and melodye
(base) Hath Palamon / ywedded Emelye
(base) And god / that al this world hath wroght
(base) Sende hym his loue / that hath it deere aboght
(base) For now is Palamon / in alle wele
(base) Lyuynge in blisse / in richesse / and in heele
(base) And Emelye / hym loueth so tendrely
(base) And he / hir serueth so gentilly
(base) That was ther no word hem bitwene
(base) Of Ialousie / or any oother teene
(base) Thus endeth Palamon / and Emelye
(base) And god saue / al this faire compaignye Amen
(base) ¶ Here is ended / the knyghtes tale
When þat þe knight had his tale tolde
In all þe company nas yonge ne olde
That he ne seide it was a noble storye
And worthy for to drawe in memorye
And namelich the gentiles euerychone
Our hooste lugh and swore so muste I goone
This goth a right vnbokeled is the male
Let se nowe whoo shall telle another tale
For truely the game is welle begonne
Nowe telle ye sir munke if that ye conne
Some what to quite with the knightes tale
The miller that for drunken was alle pale
Soo that vnneth vpon his hors hee satte
He nolde avalen neither hode ner hatte
Ne abide noman for his curtesye
But in pilates vois he ganne to crye
And swore by armes blode and bones
I can a noble tale for the nones
Wᵗith which I wille nowe quite the knightes tale
Our hoste sawe that he was drunke of ale
And seid abide Robyn leve brother
Some better man shalle telle vs firste another
Abyde . and let vs wirken thriftely
Bi goddes soule quod he that nyll nat I .
For I wille speke or elles goo my weye
Oure hooste answerd tell on a devill weye
Thou arte a fole thy witte is ouercome
Now herkeneth quod the miller all and some
But first I make a ꝓprotestacioune
That I am drunke I knowe it by my soune
And therfore if I aught mispeke or sey
Wyteth it the ale of Suthwerke I prey
For I wolle telle a legende and a life
Both of a carpenter and of his wife
How that a clerke hath set the wrightes cappe
The reve answerd and seid stint thi clappe
Lete be thi lewde drunken harlotrye
It is a synne and eke a grete folye
To apeire eny man or him diffame
And eke to bringe wifes in such name
Thou maiste y nowe of other thinges sayne
This drunken miller spake ful sone agayne
And seide leve brother Oswolde
Whoo hath no wife he is noo cokewolde
But I sey nat therfore that thou arte one
Ther ben fulle gode wives many one
Whie arte thou angry with my tale nowe
I haue a wife pardee as welle as thou
Yet nolde I for the oxenne in my plowe
Take vpon me more thenne y nowe
As demen of me selfe that I were one
I wille beleve that I am none
Anhusbonde shulde nat be inquisityfe
Of goddes priuitees ner of his wife
Soo he may finde goddes foysoune there
Of the remenaunte him nedeth nat enquere
What shulde I more seyne but this millere
He nolde his worde for no man for bere
But toke hies cherles tale in his manere
Me onthenketh that I shall reherce it here
And there fore eủer/rey gentille wight I praye
Demeth for goddes love that I saye
Nat of euille entent but for I muste reherce
Her tales all be thei bette or wers
Or elles falsen somme of my mater
And therfore who soo liste it nat to here
Turne ouer the lefe and chese another tale
For he shall finde y nowe both grete and smale
Of storiall thinge that toucheth gentilnesse
And eke moralitee and holinesse
Blameth nat me if that ye chose amys
The miller is a cherle ye knowe welle this
Soo was the reve and eke other moo
And harlotry thei tolden both twoo
Aviseth you and put me out of blame
And eke men shulde nat make erneste of game
WHilome was dwellinge at Oxenforde
A riche gnvf that gestes had to borde
And of his crafte he was a carpenter
With him there was dwellinge a pore scolere
That lerned arte but alle his fantesye
Was turned for to lerne astrologye
And coude certeine of conclusiouns
To demen by interrogaciouns
If that men axed him certein houres
When men shulde haue droughte or shoures
Or if men asked him what shulde be falle
Of eủer/rey thing I may nat reken alle
This clerke was cleped hende Nicholas
Of dierne loue he coude and of solas
And therto he was slye and fulle priuee
And like a maiden meke for to see
A chambre had he in that hostilrye
All alone withouten company
Fulle fetislye dight with herbes swote
And he him selfe as swete as is the rote
Of licorys or eny sedewale
His almegeste and bokes grete and smale
His astrolobye longinge to his arte
His awgryme stones lyen feir a parte
On shelues coached at his beddes hede
His presse couered with a faldinge rede
And all above lay a gay sawtrye
On which he made a nightes melodye
Soo swetely that all the chambre ronge
And Angelus and virginem he songe
And after that he sunge the kinges note
Fulle often blissed was his mery throte
And thus this swete clerke his tyme spente
After his frendes findinge and his rente
This carpenter had wedded newe a wyfe
Which that he loued more thenne his life
Of xviij yeres she was of age
Ielous he was and hield hir narowe in cage
For she was yonge and wilde and he was olde
And demed him self to ben like a cokewolde
He knewe nat caton for his wit was rude
That bad that menne shulde wed her similitude
shulde wedde after her estate
For yh and elde ben ofte at debate
But seth that he was fallen in the snare
He muste endure as other folke his care
Faire was this yonge wife and ther wᵗith alle
As eny wesille his bodie gentill and smalle
A seint she wered bard all with silke
A b cloth as white as morowe mylke
Vpon hir lyndes full of many a gore
White was her smok and broyded all before
And eke behinde on her coler aboute
Of cole blake silke within and eke wᵗithoute
The tappes of hir white volupere
Were of the same suyte of hir colere
Hir filette brode of silke set full hye
And sikerly she had a licorous ye
Full smale pulled were her browes twoo
And thoo were bent and blak as is a sloo
was more blisfull on to see
Thenne is the newe pere Ienet tree
And softer thenne the wolle is of a wedir
And by hir girdell hunge a purs of lether
Tasselled wᵗith silke and ꝑper/parles of latoune
In all this werlde to seken vp and doune
Ther is no man so wis that couth thenche
Soo gay a puppelet or such a wenche
Well brighter was the shynynge of hir hewe
Thenne in the toure the noble forged newe
But of hir songe she was as loude and yerne
As eny swalowe siting on a berne
Therto she couth skipp and make game
As eny kidde or calfe folowinge his dame
Hir mouth was swete as braget or methe
Or hurde of aples leide in hey or hethe
Winsinge she was as is a ioly colte
Longe as a maste and vpright as a bolte
A broche she bare in hir love colere
As brode as is the boos of a bokeler
Hir shoes were laced on her legges hye
She was a primerose a pygges nye
For eny lorde to liggen in his bedde
Or yet for eny gode man to wedde
Nowe syre and efte sir soo befell the cas
That on a day this hiende Nicholas
Fel with this yonge wife to rage ⁊and pley
While that hir husbonde was at osney
As clerkes ben fulle subtille and ful queinte
And priuely he caught hir by the queinte
And seid ywis but yf I haue my wille
For dern love of the lemman I spille
And hield hir harde by the haunch bones
And seid lemman loue all at ones
Or elles I wolle dey soo god me save
And she spronge vp as doth the colt in trave
And with hir hede wried faste awey
She seid I wille nat kisse the by my fey
Whi lat be quod she lat be hend Nicholas
Or I wolle crye out harowe and allas
Doo wey youre hondes for your curtesye
This Nicholas gan mercy for to crye
And spake soo feire and ꝓprofred him soo faste
That she hir love graunte him atte laste
And swore hir oth by seint thomas of kente
That she wolde be holy at his commaundemēmt
Whenne that she may hir leiser well espye
My husbonde is so fulle of ielousye
That but ye waite wele and be priue
I wote right wele I am but dede quod she
Ye muste bee fulle derne as in this cas
Nay ther of care ye nat quod Nicholas
A clerke had litherly beset his while
But if he couth a carpenter begile
And thus thei ben accorded and sworne
To waite a tyme as I haue seide beforne
Whenne Nicholas had done this eủer/rey dele
And thakked hir aboute the lindes wele
He kiste her swete and toke his sawtrye
And pleyeth faste and maketh melody
Thenne felle it thus that to the ꝑper/parissh chirch
Cristes owen werkes for to wirche
This goode wif on an high holy day
Hir forhede shone as bright as eny day
So was it whenne she seyd her werke
Now was ther of that chirch a ꝑper/parissh clerke
The which that cleped was absolon
Crull was his here and as the gold it shone
And strovted as a fanne large brode
Full streit and euen lay his ioly shode
His rud was rede his yen grey as goos
With powles wyndowes coruen in his shoos
In hoses rede went he fetouslye
And gladde he was well smalle and ꝓproprely
All in a kirtill of light wagette
Full feir and thik ben the pointes sette
And thervpon he had a gay a surplys
As white as is the floure on the ris
A mery childe he was so god me save
Welle couth he blode let and clipp and shave
And make a chartre of londe or aquitaunce
In twenti maners couth he tripp and daunce
After the scole of oxenforde thoo
And with his legges casten to and fro
And pleien songes on a smale ribible
Therto he song some tyme a lovde quynyble
And as wel couth he pley on a giterne
In all the toune was brewe hous ne tauerne
That he ne visited with his solas
There eny gay stapster was
But soth to sein he was some dele squeymous
Of fartinge and of spech daungerous
This absolon that ioly was and gaye
Goth with a senser on the holy daye
Sensinge wyues of the ꝑper/parissh faste
And many a lovely ye on hem he caste
And namely on this carpenters wife
To loke on hir him thought a mery life
She was soo ꝓpropre and soo likerous
I dare well seyn if she had ben a mous
And he a cat he wolde hir hent anone
This parissh clerke this ioly absolone
Hath in his hert such a love longinge
That of no wife toke he none offringe d
For curtesy he seide he wolde none
The mone whenne it was night full bright shone
And absolon his giterne hath ytake
For par amours he thought for to wake
And forth he goth iolife and amerous
Till he come to the carpenters hous
A litell er that the cokkes hadde y crowe
And dressed him vp by a shotte windowe
That was vpon the carpenters walle
He singeth in his voys gentille and smalle
Nowe dere lady if thi wille bee
I pray you that ye wille rewe on me
Fulle welle accordante to his giternynge
This carpenter a woke and harde him singe
And spake to his wife and seid anone
What alison hereste thou nat absolone
That chaunteth thus vnder our bowres walle
And she answerd hir husbonde with alle
Yes god wote Iohn I here him eủer/rey dele
This passed forth what wille ye more then wele
Frome day to day this ioly absolone
So woweth hir that him is woo begone
He waked all the night and all the day
He kempte his lokkes brode and made him gay
He woweth hir by menes and by brocage
And swore he wolde ben her owen page
He singeth brockinge as a nightingale
He sente hir pymente and spiced ale
And wafres pipinge hote oute of the glede
And for she was of toune he ꝓprofred hir mede
For some folke wolle be wonne for richesse
And some for strokes and some for gentilnesse
Some tyme to shewe his maistrye
He pleyeth herodes on a scaffolde hye
But what availleth it him in this cas
She loueth soo this hende Nicholas
That absolon may blowe the buckes horne
He ne hadde for his labour but a scorne
And thus she maketh absolon hir ape
And all his ernest turneth in to a Iape
Full sooth is this ꝓprouerbe it is no lye
Mene seyne alle the nigh ys slye
And maketh the fer liefe too be lothe
For though that absoloıı̄un be woode or wroth
Be cause that he was ferre frome hir sight
This nigh Nicholas stode in his light
Nowe bere the wele hende Nicholas
For absolon may weill and singe allas
And soo befelle that on a saterday
This carpenter was goone to osney
And hende Nicholas and alisoune
Accorded bee to this conclusioune
That Nicholas shall shapen him a wyle
This sely ielous husbonde to be gile
And if soo bee the game went a right
She shulde slepe in his arme al night
For this was his desire and hir alsoo
And right anone without wordes moo
This Nicholas no lenger wolde tarye
But doth full softe vnto his chambre cary
Both mete and drinke for a day or twey
And to hir husbonde he badde hir for to sey
If that he asked after Nicholas
She shulde seyne she nyste where he was
Of alle that day she sawe him nat with yie
She trowed that he is in maledye
For no crye hir mayde couth him calle
He nolde answere for aught that may be falle
This passeth forth all thilke sater daye
That Nicholas stille in his chambre laye
And ete and slepe and didde what him liste
Tyll sunday that sonne goth too reste
This ielous carpenter hath muche merveill
Of Nicholas what thing might him eyll
And seid I am a dradde by seint thomas
It stondeth nat a right with Nicholas
God shelde it that he sodeinly
This worlde is fulle tikell sekerly
I sawe to daye a cors borne to chirche
That nowe on munday laste I sawe him wirche
Goo vp quod he vn to his knave anone
Clepe at his dore or knok with a stone
Looke howe it is and tell me boldelye
This knave anone goth vp full sturdely
And at the chambre dore while that he stode
He cried and knokked as he hadde been wode
What howe what doo ye maister Nicholay
Howe may ye slepen all the longe day
But all for nought he herde nat oo worde
An hole he founde fulle lowe vpon a borde
Where as catte was wont in to crepe
And at that hole he loked in full depe
And at the laste he had of him a sight
This Nicholas sat euer gapinge vp right
As he hadde keked vpon the newe mone
Adoune he goth and tolde his maister sone
In what array he sawe that ilke manne
This carpenter to blissen him beganne
And seide helpe vs seint Frissewide
A man wote litle what shalle him betyde
This man is falle with his astronemye
In somme wodenesse or in some agonye
I thought ay howe it shulde bee
Menne shulde nat knowe goddes priuite
Y blessed be alwey a lewde manne
That nat but onely his beleve canne
Soo ferde another clerke with astronomye
He walked in too the feldes for to prye
Vpon the sterres what shulde befalle
Tille he was in a marle pitte y falle
He sawe nat that but yet by seinte thomas
Me reweth sore of hende Nicholas
He shall be rated of his studyinge
If that I may by ihu heuen kinge
Gete me a staffe that I may vnderspore
While that thou robyn heuest vp the dore
He shalle out of his studyinge I gesse
And to the chambre dore he gan him dresse
His knave was a stronge cherle for the nones
And by the haspe he lefte it vp at ones
In to the flore the dore felle anone
This Nicholas sat ay as stille as stone
And euer gaped vpwarde in to the heire
This carpenter wende he hadde ben in dispeire
And hente him by the shuldres mightelye
And shoke him harde and cried pitouslye
What Nicholas what howe loke a doune
Awake and thenke on cristes passioune
I crouche the from elues and from wightes
Therwith the night spelle seide he anone rightes
On foure halfe of the hous aboute
And on the thressfolde of the dore wᵗithoute
Ihu criste and seint benedight
Blesse this hous frome eủer/rey wicked wight
For the nightes nery the white pater noster
Where wonnest thou seint petres suster
And at the laste this hende Nicholas
Ganne for to sike sore and seid allas
Shall all the worlde be loste efte sones nowe
This carpenter answerd what seiste thoue
What thenke on god as we doo men that swynke
This Nicholas answerde fet me drinke
And after wolle I speke in priuitee
Of certein thinge that toucheth the and me
I wolle telle it none other man certeine
This carpenter goth doune and commeth ageine
And brought of mighti ale a large quarte
And whenne that eche of hem had drunke his parte
This Nicholas his dore faste shette
And doun the carpenter by him he sette
And seid Iohn myne hooste liefe and dere
Thou shalte vpon thi trouth swere me here
