div.l: Tille that the belle of lawdes ganne to ringe
And freres in the quere ganne to singe
This parissh clerke this amerous absoloune
That is for love alwey soo woo begone
Vpon the munday was at Osenaye
With company him to disporte and playe
And asked vpon cas a cloysterer
Welle priuely after Iohn the carpenter
The munke him drowe a parte out of the chirch
And seide I note I sawe him nat here wirch
Seth saterday I trowe that he be wente
For tymber thider that oure Abbot him sente
For he is wonte for tymber for to goo
And dwellen at the graunge a day or twoo
Or elles he is at his hous certeine
Where that he bee I can nat seyne
This absolon full ioly was and light
And thought nowe is tyme to walke all nyght
For sekerly I sawe him nat steringe
Aboute his dore sen day beganne to springe
So mote I thryve I shall at cockes crowe
Full priuely knok at his windowe
That stante full lowe vpon his bowres wall
To Alisoun nowe woll I tellen all
My love longinge for yet I shall n
That at the leste wey I shall hir kysse
Some maner comforte shall I haue parfeye
My mouthe hath icched all thes longe daye
That is a signe of kissinge at the leste
All night I met eke that I was at the feste
Therfore I will goo slepe an houre or twey
And all the night thenne woll I wake and pley
Whenne that the firste cok hath crowe anone
Vp riste this ioly louer Absolon
And him arraieth gay at pointe deuys
But firste he cheweth greyne and licorys
To smellen swete er he had kempte his here
Vnder his tunge a trewe love he bere
For therby wende he to bee gracious
He renneth to the carpenters hous
And stille he stonte vnder the shot windowe
Vnto his breste it raught it was soo lowe
And softe he singeth with a mery soune
What doo ye hony combe swete Alisoune
My faire bridde my swete cynomomee
A waketh lemman myne and speke too mee
Fulle litle thinken yee vpon my woo
That for your loue I swelte there I goo
No wonder is though I swelte and swete
I murne as doth a lambe for the tete
Ywis lemman I haue such loue longinge
That like a turtill trewe is my murnynge
I may nat ete nomore thenne a mayde
Goo from the windowe iak fole she sayde
As helpe me godde he woll nat be come pame
I love another and elles I were to blame
Well bette thenne the by ihu absolone
Goo forth thy wey or I woll caste a stone
And let me slepe a twenty devill wey
Allas quod absolon and wele awey
That true love was euer soo evill besette
Thenne kisse me seth it may be no bette
For iesus love and for the love of me
Wilte thou thenne goo thy wey quoth she
Ye certes lemman quoth this Absolon
Thenne make the redy quod she I come anone
This Absolon doune sette him on his knees
And seide I am a lorde at all degrees
For after this I hope ther commeth more
Lemman thy grace and swete bridde thyn ore
The windowe she vndoth and that in haste
Haue doo quoth she come of and spede the faste
Leste that oure neighburghes the espye
This absolon ganne wipe his mouth full drye
Derke was the night as pitche or as a cole
And at the windowe oute she putte hir hole
And Absolon felte neither bette ne wers
But with his mouth he kiste hir naked ers
Full sauourely er he were ware of this
Abak he sterte and thought it was amys
For wele he wiste a womman had no berde
He felte a thinge rowgh and longe herede
And seide fye allas what haue I doo
Te hee quod she and clapte the windowe too
And absolon goth forth a sory pace
A berde a berde seide hiende Nicholas
By goddes corps this goth ferre and wele
This cely absolon harde euerydele
And on his lippes he ganne for anger byte
And to him self he seide I shall the quyte
Who rubbeth nowe who froteth nowe his lippes
Wᵗith duste wᵗith sonde wᵗith strawe wᵗith cloth wᵗith chippes
But absolon that seith full ofte allas
My soule betake I nowe too sathanas
But me were leuer thenne all this toun ꝙquod hee
Of this despite avenged forto bee
Allas quod he allas I ne hadde bleinte
His hote love was colde and all y queinte
For from that tyme that he had kiste hir ers
Of paramours he sette nat a kers
For he was heledde of his maledy
Full ofte par amours he gen defye
And wepe as doth a childe that ys y bete
A softe pas he wente ouer the strete
Vnto a smyth men clepen daun gerueys
That in his forge smyteth plowe herneys
He sharpeth share and culter beselye
This absolon knokketh all easelye
And seide vndoo gerueys and that anone
What whoo arte thou it am I absolone
What absolon what cristes swete tree
Why rise ye soo rath ey benedicitee
What eilleth you some gay girle god wote
Hath brought you nowe in the viritote
By seint Nutte ye wote wele what I mene
This Absolon rought nat a beene
Of all this pley noo worde he gaffe
He hadde more towe on his distaffe
Thenne gerueis knewe and seid frende soo dere

This Nicholas was risen for to pisse

This Nicholas anone let flee a ferte
As grete as itte hadde been a thunder dynte

And he was redye with his ironne hote
And Nicholas in the ers he smote
Of gothe the skynne an hande brede aboute
The hote cultre brente soo his toute
That for the smerte he wende for to deye
As he were wode for woo he ganne crye
Helpe water water helpe for goddes herte
This carpenter oute of his slumber sterte
And herde one crye water as he were wode
And thought allas nowe commeth Noes flode
And set him vp wᵗithoute wordes moo
And with his axe he smote the corde a twoo
And doun he goth he founde neither to sell
Ner brede ner ale tille he come to the sell
Vpon the flore and there on swoune he lay
Vp stirte hir Alisoun and Nicholay
And criden oute and harowe in the strete
The neighburghs both smale and grete
In ronnen for to gawren on this manne
That yet in swowe lay both pale and wanne
For with the fall bresten was his arme
But stonde he muste vn to his owen harme
For whenne he spak . he was anone born doune
With hiende Nicholas and Alisoune
Thei tolde eủer/rey manne that he was wode
He was agaste soo of Noes flode
Thurgh fantesye that of his fanitee
He hadde bought him knedinge tubbes three
And hadde hem honged in the roofe above
And that he preide hem for goddes love
To sitten in the roofe par companye
The folke ganne laughen at this fantesye
And to the roofe they kiken and they gape
And turned all his harme in to a Iape
For what soo that the carpenter answerd
It was for nought no man his resonne herd
With grete othes he was soo borne a doune
That he was holde madde thurghout the toune
For euery clerke anone hielde with other
They seid the manne was wode my lief brother
And euery wight ganne laughen at his stryfe
Thus swyued was the carpenters wyfe
For all his kepynge and all his Ielousye
And absoloune hath kiste hir nether yie
And Nicholas is scalded in the toute
This tale ys doone and god save all the route

div.l: That to no wight thou shalte this counseill wrey
For it is cristes counseill that I seye
And if thou telle it euy man thou arte forlore
For this vengeaunce thou shalte haue therfore
That if thou wrey me thou shalte bee wode
Nay criste forbede it for his holy blode
Quod thoo this sely man I am no labbe
And though I sey it I am nat lief to gabbe
Sey what thou wilte I shall it neuer telle
To childe ner wife by him that harowed helle
Nowe Iohn quod Nicholas I wille nat lye
I haue founden in myne Astrologye
As I haue loked in the mone brighte
That nowe on munday next at quarter night
Shalle falle a reyne and that soo wilde ⁊and wode
That halfe soo grete was neuer Noes flode
This werlde he seide in lesse thenne in an houre
Shalle alle be dreinte soo hidous is that shoure
Thus shall man kinde drench ⁊and lese his life
This carpenter answerde allas my wife
And shalle she drench allas myn alisoune
For sorowe of this almoste he fille adoune
And seid is there no remedye in this caas
Whi yes for god quod hende Nicholas
If thou wirken after lore and rede
Thou might nat wirken after thine own hede
For thus seith salamon that was full true
Werke by counseill and thou shalt nat rue
And if thou wirken wilte by gode counseill
I vndertake withoute maste or saill
Yet shall I save hir and thee and me
Haste thou nat herde howe saued was Noe
Whenne that our lorde had warned him beforne
That alle the werlde wᵗith water shulde be lorne
Yis quod this carpenter well yore agoo
Haste thou nat herde quod Nicholas alsoo .
The sorowe of Noe with his felawshippe
Er he myght gete his wife in too the shippe
Him had ben leuer I dare vndertake
At thilke tyme thenne alle his wethres blake
That she hadde beene by hir self alone
And therfore wooste thou what is beste to doone
This asketh haste and of hasty thinge
Menne may nat prech ner maken tariynge
Anone goo gete vs in to this Iune
A knedinge trough or elles a kemelynne
For eche of vs but loke that thei be large
In which that we mowe swymme as in a barge
And thenne therin vitailles suffisaunte
But for one day fye on the remenaunte
The water shall aslake and goone awaye
Aboute pryme vpon the next daye
But Robin may nat wete of this thi knave
Neither thy maiden Iill I may nat save
Aske nat whie for thou thou aske mee
I woll nat tellen goddes pryuitee
Suffiseth the but if thi wittes madde
To haue as grete grace as Noee hadde
Thi wife shall I save withoute doute
Goo nowe thi wey and spede the here aboute
But whanne thou for hir thee and mee
Geten haste thise knedinge tubbes three
Thou shalt hem honge in the roof on hie
That noman of our puruestance espie
And whenne thou haste doone as I haue seide
And haste oure vitailles feir in hem leide
And eke an axe to smyte the corde on twoo
Whenne that the water commeth that we may goo
And breke an hole an hie vpon the gable
Vnto the garden warde ouer the stable
That we may frely passe forth our weye
Whenne that grete shoure is gone aweye
Thenne shalt thou swymme as mery I vndertake
As doth the white dove after the drake
Thenne wilte thou clepe howe Alison howe Iohn
Be mery for the flode wolle passe anone
And thou wilte seye heill maister Nicholay
Gode morowe I see the well for it ys day
And thenne we shull be lordes all oure life
Of all the worlde as Noe and his wife
But of one thinge I warne the full right
Be wele avised on that ilke night
That we bee entred in to the shippes borde
That none of vs speke nat oo worde
Ne clepe ne crie but be in his prayere
For it ys goddes owen hest dere
Thy wife and thou muste honge ferre atwynne
For that betwix you shall be no synne
Nomore in lokinge thenne ther shall in dede
This ordenaunce is seide goo god the spede
To morowe nyght whenne men ben all in slepe
In to oure knedinge tubbes woll we crepe
And sitten there abidynge goddes grace
Goo nowe thi wey I haue no lenger space
To make of this no lenger sermonynge
Menne seyn thus sende the wise and sey no thinge
Thou arte so wis it nede nat the to teche
Goo save oure life and that I the beseche
This sely carpenter goth forth his waye
Full ofte he seide allas and wele aweye
And too his wife he tolde his priuitee
And she was ware and knewe it bet thenne hee
What all this queinte caas was for to sey
But natheles she ferde as she wolde deye
And seid allas goo forth thy wey anone
Helpe vs to scape or we be dede
I am thy trewe verrey wedded wyfe
Goo dere spouse and help to save our lyfe
Loo swich a grete thinge is affeccioune
Menne may dey of ymaginacioune
Soo depe may ympression be take
This sely carpenter begynneth to quake
Him thinketh verrely that he may see
Noes flode commynge faste ayee
To drenchen Alisoune his hony dere
He wepeth wailleth maketh sory chere
He syketh full many a sorye swowe
And goth and geteth him a knedinge trowe
And after a tubbe and a kemelynne
And priuely he sent hem to his ynne
And hinge hem in the roofe in priuitee
His owen honde he made laddres three
To clymbe by the renges and the stalkes
Vnto the tubbes hanginge in the balkes
And hem vitailled both trowgh and tubbe
With brede and chese and gode ale in a Iubbe
Suffisinge right ynough as for a day /
But er that he made all this arraye
He sente his knave and eke his wench alsoo
Vpon his nede to lundoıı̄un for to goo
And on the munday whenne it drough to night
He shute his dore withoute candell light
And dressed all thinge as it shulde bee
And shortly vp thei clumben all three
Thei seten stille well a furlonge weye
Now pater noster clum quod Nicholaye
And clum quod Iohn and clum quod Alisoune
This carpenter seid his deuocioune
And stille he sytte and biddeth his prayere
Awaytinge on the reyne if he it here
The dede slepe for verrey besynesse
Fell on this carpenter right as I gesse
Aboute curfue tyme or litle more
For trauaill of his gooste he groneth soore
And efte he routeth for his hede myslaye
Doune of the ladder stalketh Nicholaye
And Alisoun full softe adoune she spedde
Withoute wordes moo they goone to bedde
There as the carpenter is wonte to lye
There was the reuell and the melodye
Thus lieth Alisoune and Nicholas
In besynesse in myrth and in solas

div.l: (base) ¶ hic incipit fabula

div.l: (base) For al oure craft whan we han al ydo

(base) And with the senatoure she led hir life
(base) Thus can oure lorde god bringe hir out of woo
(base) Woofull Constaunce and many another moo
(base) And longe tyme dwelte she in that place
(base) In holy werkes euer as was hir grace
(base) ¶ The Senatours wife hir aunte was
(base) But for all that she knewe hir neủer/re the more
(base) I wolle no lenger tary in this cas
(base) But to kinge alla which I spake of yore
(base) That for his wife wepeth and siketh sore
(base) I woll returne and let I woll of constaunce
(base) Vnder the senatours gouernaunce
(base) ¶ King Alla which that hath his moder slayne
(base) Vpon a day fell in such repentaune
(base) That yf I shall shortely seyn and pleyne
(base) To Rome he comth to resceyue his penaunce
(base) And to put him in the popes ordenaunce
(base) In high and lowe and ihu criste besought
(base) For yeve the wicked werke that he had wrought
(base) ¶ The fame anone thurgh out rome ys borne
(base) Howe kinge Alla shall come in pilgrimage
(base) By herbergers that wenten him beforne
(base) For which the senatoure as was vsage
(base) Rode him agein and many of his lynage
(base) As well to shewen his magnificence
(base) As to done eny kinge a reuerence
(base) ¶ Grete chere doth this noble senatoure
(base) To king alla and he to him alsoo
(base) Eủer/reych of hem doth other grete honoure
(base) And soo befell that in a day or twoo
(base) This senatoure ys to kinge Alla goo
(base) To feste and shortly yf I shall nat lye
(base) Constaunces son goth in his company
(base) ¶ Some men wolde sey at requeste of constaunce
(base) This senatoure hath led this childe to feste
(base) I may nat tellen eủer/rey circumstaunce

div.l: (base) Be as be /may ther was he at the leste

(base) Biforn /Alla duryng the metes space
(base) The child /stood lookynge in the kynges face
(base) This Alla kyng hath of this child greet wonder
(base) And to the /Senatour he seyde anon
(base) Whos is that faire /child that stondeth yonder
(base) I noot quod /he by god and by Seint Iohn
(base) A moder he /hath but fader hath he non
(base) That I of woot and shortly in a stounde
(base) He tolde /Alla how that this child was founde
(base) But god woot quod this Senatour also
(base) So vertuous a /lyuere in my lyf
(base) Ne saw I neuere as /she ne herde of mo
(base) Of worldly /wommen mayde ne of wyf
(base) I dar wel /seyn hir hadde leuere a knyf
(base) Thurgh out hir brest than been a womman wikke
(base) Ther is no /man koude brynge hire to that prikke
(base) Now was this /child as lyk vnto Custaunce
(base) As possible /is a creature to be
(base) This /Alla hath the face in remembraunce
(base) Of dame /Custaunce and ther on mused he
(base) If that the childes /moder were aught she
(base) That is his /wyf and pryuely he sighte
(base) And spedde hym fro the table that he myghte
(base) fay thoughte /he fantome is in myn heed
(base) I oghte /deme of skilful Iugement
(base) That in the salte /see my wif is deed
(base) And /afterward he made his argument
(base) What woot /I if that Crist hath hider sent
(base) My wif by /See as wel as he hir sente
(base) To my /contree from thennes that she wente
(base) And after /noon hom with the Senatour
(base) Goth /Alla for to seen this wonder chaunce
(base) This /Senatour dooth Alla greet honour
(base) And /hastily he sente after Custaunce
(base) But tristeth /wel hir liste noght to daunce
(base) Whan that she /wiste wher fore was that sonde
(base) /Vnnethe vpon hir feet she myghte stonde
(base) Whan Alla saugh his /wyf faire he hir grette
(base) And /weep that it was routhe for to se
(base) For at the firste /look he on hir sette
(base) He knew wel /verraily that it was she
(base) And she for /sorwe as domb stant as a tree
(base) So was hir herte shet in hir distresse
(base) Whan she /remembred his vnkyndenesse
(base) Twies she /swowneth in his owene sighte
(base) He /weep and hym excuseth pitously
(base) Now god quod /he and his halwes brighte
(base) So wisly on my /soule as haue mercy
(base) That of youre /harm as giltlees am I
(base) As is Maurice my /sone so lyk youre face
(base) Ellis the /feend me fecche out of this place
(base) Long was the sobbyng and the bitter peyne
(base) Er /that hir woful hertes myghte cesse
(base) Greet was the /pitee for to heere hem pleyne
(base) Thurgh whiche /pleintes gan hir wo encresse
(base) I pray /yow al my labour to relesse
(base) I may nat telle hir /wo vn til to morwe
(base) I am so /wery for to speke of sorwe
(base) But /finally whan that the sooth is wist /
(base) That /Alla giltlees was of hir wo
(base) I /trowe an hundred tymes been they kist
(base) And swich a /blisse is ther bitwix hem two
(base) That saue the /ioye that lasteth eueremo
(base) Ther is noon /lyk that any creature
(base) Hath /seyn or /shal whil that the world may dure
(base) Tho preyde /she hir housbond mekely
(base) In /relief of hir longe pitous pyne
(base) That he wolde /praye hir fader specially
(base) That of his /magestee he wolde enclyne
(base) To vouche /sauf som day with hym to dyne
(base) She preyde hym eek he sholde by no weye
(base) Vnto hir /fader no word of hir seye
(base) Som men wolde /seyn how that the child Mauryce
(base) Dooth this /message vnto this Emperour

div.l: (base) But as I gesse Alla was nat soo nyce
(base) To him that was of so soủer/reeigne honoure
(base) As he that was of cristen folke the floure
(base) Sente eny childe but yt is beste to deme
(base) He wente him selfe and so it may well seme
(base) ¶ This emꝑper/paroure hath graunted gentilly
(base) To come to diner as he him besoughte
(base) And welle I rede he loked besely
(base) Vpon this childe and on his doughter thought
(base) Alla goth to his Inne and as him ought
(base) Arrayed for the feste in eủer/rey wise
(base) As ferforth as his connynge may suffise
(base) ¶ The morowe com and alla gan him dresse
(base) And eke his wife the emꝑper/paroure to mete
(base) And forth thei ryde in ioy and in gladnesse
(base) And whenne she sawe hir fader in the strete
(base) She light a doıı̄unn and falleth to his fete
(base) Fader quod she your yonge childe Constaunce
(base) Is nowe fulle clene oute of yoᵘur remembraunce
(base) ¶ I am your doughter Constaunce quod shee
(base) That whilome ye sente in to Surrye
(base) It am I fader that in the salte see
(base) Was put allone and dampned for to dye
(base) Nowe gode fader mercy I you crye
(base) Sende me nomore vnto none hethennesse
(base) But thonke my lorde here of his kindenesse
(base) ¶ Whoo can the pitous ioy tellen alle
(base) Betwix hem thre seth they ben thus ymette
(base) But of my tale make an ende I shall
(base) The day goth faste I will no lenger lette
(base) Thise glade folke to dyner they ben sette
(base) In ioy and blisse at mete I let hem dwelle
(base) A thousand folde welmore then I can tell
(base) ¶ This childe Mauryce was sithen emꝑper/paroure
(base) Made by the pope and lyued cristenlye
(base) To cristes chirche he didde grete honoure
(base) But I lete all this story passen by
(base) Of Constaunce ys my tale specially
(base) In olde romayne gestes men may fynde
(base) Mauricius life I bere it nat in mynde
(base) ¶ This kinge Alla whenne he his tyme saye
(base) With Constaunce his holy wife swete
(base) To Inglonde ben they come the right wey
(base) Where as they lyuen in ioye and quiete
(base) But litill while it lasteth I you hete
(base) Ioy of of this worlde for tyme woll nat abyde
(base) From day to night it chaungeth as the tyde
(base) ¶ Whoo lyued euir in such delite a daye
(base) That him ne moued outher conscience
(base) Or Ire or talente or some kene affraye
(base) Enuy or pryde or passioun or offence
(base) I ne sey but for this ende this sentence
(base) That litle while in ioy or in plesaunce
(base) Lasteth the blisse of Alla with Constaunce
(base) ¶ For deth that taketh of high and lowe his rente
(base) Whenne passed was a yere even as I gesse
(base) Oute of this worlde this king Alla he hente
(base) For whom constaunce hath full grete heuynesse
(base) Nowe let vs prayen god his soule blesse
(base) And dame constaunce finally to seye
(base) Towarde the toıı̄unn of rome taketh hir weye
(base) ¶ To rome ys come this holy creature
(base) And findeth hir frendes hole and sounde
(base) Nowe ys she scaped all hir auenture
(base) And she hir fader also hath yfounde
(base) Doıı̄unn on knees falleth she to grounde
(base) Wepinge for tendirnesse in herte blithe
(base) She heryeth god an hundred thousande sithe
(base) ¶ In vertu and in holy almesse dede
(base) They lyuen ay and neuer a sunder wende
(base) Till deth ꝑper/parteth hem this life they lede
(base) And fare nowe wele my tale ys at an ende
(base) Nowe ihu criste that of his might may sende
(base) Ioy after woo goủer/rene vs in his grace
(base) And kepe vs all that ben in this place

div.l: Experience though none auctoritee
Were in this werlde right ynowe for me
To speke of woo that ys in maryage
For lordinges seth I was twelue yere of age
Thanked be god that ys eterne on lyve
Husbondes at the chirch I haue had fyve
If I so ofte might wedded bee
And al were worthy men in her degree
But me was tolde certein nat longe agone ys
That seth that criste wente neuir but ones
Herke eke which a sharp worde for the nonce
Beside a wel ihu god and manne
Spake in re pref of the samarytanne
Thou haste hadde fyve husbondes quod hee
And that ilke man that nowe hath thee
Is nat thy husbonde thus he seid certeine
What he mente there by I can nat seyne
But that I aske why that the fyfte manne
Was none husbonde to the samarytanne
Howe might she han in maryage
Yed harde I neuer tellen in myne age
Vpon this noumbre diffinicioune
Men may deuyne and glose vp and doun
But wel I wote expresse withouten lye
God bad vs wex and multeplye
That gentil text wel can I vnderstonde
Eke wel I wote he seid that myne husbonde
Shulde leve fader and moder and take me
But of none noumbre mencion made hee
Of bygamye or of octogamy
Whi shulde men thenne speke of yt vilanye
Loo here the wise kinge daun salamon
I trowe he hadde wyues moo then one
As wolde godde yt lieful were to me
To bee refresshed halfe soo ofte as hee
Which yifte of god had he for al his wyues
No man swich that in this werlde on lyve is
God wote this noble kinge as to my witte
The firste night hath many a mery fytte
With eche of hem soo wel was he on lyve
Blessed be god that I haue wedded fyve
Welcome the sext whenne that euer he sal
For soth I wol nat kepe me chaste in al
Whenne myne husbonde ys from the worlde gone
Some cristen man shal wedden me anone
He seith to be wedded ys no synne
Better ys be wedded thenne to brenne
I wote wel Abraham was an holy man
And Iacob eke as ferre as euir I can
And eche of hem had wyues moo then twoo
And many another holy manne alsoo
Here canne ye seen in eny maner age
That hie god ne defendeth maryage
By expresse worde I pray you telleth mee
Or whether commaundeth he virginitee
I wote as wel ytte ys no drede
Thappostel whenne he speketh of maydenhede
He seith that precept therof hath he none
Men may counseil a womman to be one
But counseillinge ys noo commaundemente
He putteth it in oure owen iuggemente
For had god commaunded maydenhede
Thenne had be dampned wedding wᵗith the dede
And certes if there were no sede ysowe
Virginitee then wherof shulde it growe
The darte ys sette vpon virginitee
Catch who so may who renneth beste lat see
But this worde ys nat taken of eủer/rey wight
But there that leste yefe of his might
I wote wel that thappostel was a mayde
But nathelesse though that he wrote or seide
Al is but counseil to virginitee
He wolde that eủer/rey wight were swich as hee
And for too ben a wife he yaue me leve
Of indulgence so it ys no repreve
To wedde me yf my make dye
Withoute excepcioune of bygamye
Al were it gode no womman for touche
He mente as in his bedde or in his couche
For ꝑper/parel ys bothe fire and towe to assemble
Ye knowe what this ensaumple may resemble
This is al and some he hielde virginitee
More ꝑper/parfite in weddinge in freltee
Freltee clepe I if hee and shee
Wolde leden her life in chastitee
I graunte welle I haue noone envy
Though maydenhede preferre bygamy
It liketh hem to bee clene in body and gooste
Of myn estate wol I make noo boste
For wel ye knowe a lorde in his housholde
Hath nat eủer/rey vessel al of golde
Some been of tree and done her lorde ʆser/siruice
God kepeth to him folke of sundry wise
And euich hath of godde a ꝑper/parfite yifte
Some this . some that . as him liketh shifte
Virginitee is grete perfeccioune
And contynence eke with deuocioune
But criste that ys of ꝑper/parfeccioun the welle
Bad nat eủer/rey wight he shulde goo selle
Alle that he hadde and yeve it to the pore
And in such wise folowe him and his lore
He spake to him that wolde live ꝑper/parfitelye
And lordinges by youre leve that am nat I .
I wil bestowe the floure of al myn age
In the actes and fruyte of maryage
Telle me alsoo to what conclusioun
Were membres made of generacioun
And of soo ꝑper/parfite wise a wight y wroughte
Trusteth right wele they were nat made for nought
Glose whoo so wol and sey both vp and doun
That they were made for purgacioun
Of vryne and of bothe thinges smale
Was eke to knowe a femel from a male .
And for none other cause sey ye noo
Thexꝑper/parience wote wele it is nat soo
Soo that the clerkes be nat with me wrothe
I sey this that they maked be for bothe
That is to sey for offyce and for ease
For engendrure there we nat god displese
Whie shulde men elles in her bokes sette
That man shal yelde to his wife his dette
Nowe where with shulde he paie his paymente
If he ne vsed his sely instrumente
Thenne were they made vpon a creature
To purge vryne and for engendrure
But I sey nat that eủer/rey wight is holde
That hath such harmes as I of tolde
To gone and vsen hem in engendrure
Thenne men shulde take of chastitee no cure
Criste was a maide and shapen as a manne .
And many a seinte seth the werlde beganne .
Yet lyued they euir in ꝑper/parfite chastitee
And hadde none envy to virginitee
Let hem ete brede of pured whete sede
And let vs wyues eten barly brede
And yet with barly brede marke tel canne
Oure lorde ihu refresshed many a manne
In such estate as god hath cleped vs
I wol ꝑper/parseuer I am nat precious
In wifhode wol I vse myn instrumente
As frely as my maker me yt sente
If I be daungerous god yeve me sorowe
Myn husbonde shal it haue both eve ⁊and morowe
Whenne him liste come forth ⁊and pay his dette
An husbonde wol I haue I wol nat lette
Which shal be both my dettoure and my thral
And haue his tribulacioun with al
Vpon his flessh the while I am his wife
I haue the power during al my life
Vpon his body ꝓpropre and not hee .
Right thus the Appostel telleth to me
And bad oure husbondes for to love vs wele
Al this sentence me liketh eủer/rey dele
Vp sterte the perdoner and that anone
Now dame quod he by seint Iohne
Ye ben anoble prechoure as in this cas
I was a boute to wedde a wife allas
What shulde I by it on my flessh soo dere
Yet had I leuer to wedde no wife to yere
Abyde quod she my tale ys nat begonne
Nay thou shalt drinken of another tonne
Er that I goo shal sauoure other then ale
And whenne I haue tolde the forth my tale
Of tribulacioun in mariage
Of which I am experte in al myn age
This is to seyne me selfe haue ben the whipp
Thenne may thou chese whethir thou wilte skipp
Of thilke tonne that I shal abroche
Beware of ytte or thou to ny it approche
For I shal tel ensaumples mo then ten
Whoo soo wol not beware by other men
By hem shal other men corrected bee
Thise same wordes writeth ꝓprotholome
Rede in his almageste and take it there
Dame I wolde pray you yf your wil were
Seide the ꝑper/pardoner as ye beganne
Tel forth youre tale and spare for no man
And tech vs yonge men of your practyke
Gladly quod she seth I may you lyke
But I pray to al this company
If that I speke after my fantasye
Taketh noo greef of that I seye .
For myn entente ys but for to pleye
Nowe sire I wol tel yoᵘ forth my tale
As eủer/re mote I drynke wyne or ale
I shal sey soth the husbondes that I hadde
Ay thre of hem were gode and thre were badde
The three men were riche and gode and olde
Vnneth ne might they the statute holde
In which they were bounden vn to me
Ye wote what I mene of this ꝑper/pardee
As helpe me god I laugh whenne I thinke
Howe pitously on nyght I made hem swynke
But by me feith I tolde of it no store
They had yeve me hir londe and tresore
Me neded to doo no lenger diligence
To wynne her love or done hem reủer/reence
They loued me soo welle by god above
That I ne tolde no deinte of her love
A wise womman wol busy hir euir in one
To gete hir love there she hath none
But seth I hadde hem holy in my
And seth they had yeve me al their londe
What shulde shulde I take kepe to plese
But yt were my ꝓprofyte and myn ease
I sette hem soo on werke by my feye
That many a night they sungen wele awey
The bacon was nat for hem I trowe
That some men han in essex at Dunmowe
I goủer/rened hem soo after my lawe
That eche of hem ful blisful were and fawe
To bringe me gay thinges from
They were fulle glade whenne I spake to hem feire
For god wote I chidde with hem pitouslye
Nowe herken nowe howe I bare me ꝓproprelye
Ye wise wyues that connen vnderstonde
Thus shulde ye speke and bere hem wronge on honde
For halfe so boldely ther can no man
Swere and ly as a womman can
I sey nat this ben wyues that ben wise
But it be whenne they ben mysavise
A wise wyfe that canne wel hir goode
Shal bere him on honde the cowe ys wode
And take witnesse of hir owen mayde
Of hir assente but herken howe I sayde
Sir olde kaynarde is this thine arraye
Why is myn neighburs wife soo gaye
She ys honoured ouir al there she gothe
I sitte at home and haue no thrifty cloth
What dooste thou at my neigburs hous
Is she soo feire arte thou soo amerous
What rowne with hir maide benedicitee
Sir olde lechoure let thy Iapes bee
And If I haue a gode sybbe or a frende
Withouten gilte ye shullen as a fende
If I walke or pley vnto his hous
Thou comste home as drunken as a mous
And precheste on thy benche with evil preefe
Thus seyste thou to me it is a grete myschiefe
To wedde a poủer/ree womman for costage
And if she be riche and hie of parage
Then seiste thou that yt ys a turmentrye
To suffre hir pryde and hir malincolye
And if that she be feire thou verrey knave
Thou seiste that eủer/rey holoure wol hir have
She may no while in chastitee abyde
That ys assaylled vpon euery side
Thou seiste some folke desiren vs for richesse
Some for oure shapp some for oure feirenesse
Some for she can singe or elles daunce
And some for gentilnesse and daliaunce
Some tyme for hir hondes and armes smale
Thus goth al to the deuyl by thy tale
Thou seiste men may nat kepe a castel wal
It may so longe been assailled ouer al
And if that she be foul thou seiste that shee
Coueyteth eủer/rey man that she may see
For as a spaynel she wil on him lepe
Til that she finde some man hir to chepe
Ne none soo grey goos goth there in the lake
As thou seiste wolle bee withoute a make
And seyste it is an harde thinge for to wolde
A thinge that noman wol by his thonkes holde
Thou seiste thou lorel whenne thou gooste to bedde
And that no wise man nedeth for to wedde
Noo man that entendeth vn too heuen
With wilde fire and thundre dynte ⁊and leuen
Mote thy wicked nekke be to broke
Thou seiste that dreppinge hous ande eke smoke
And chidinge wifes make men to flee
Out of hir houses A benedicitee
What eilleth such an olde man to chide
Thou seiste we wyues wol oure vices hide
Tyl we ben faste and thenne we wil hem shewe
Welle may that bee a ꝓprouerbe of a shrewe
Thou seiste that oxen asses hors and houndes
They ben assayed on diuers stoundes
Basyns lauoures er that men hem bye
Stoles spones and al such husbondrye
And soo ben pottes clothes and arraye
But folke of wyues maken none assaye
Tyl they ben wedded olde dotarde shrewe
And thenne seiste thou we wil oure vices shewe
Thou seiste also that it despleseth mee
But if thou wilte preysen my beautee
And but thou pore alwey in my face
And clepe me feire dame in eủer/rey place
And but thou make a feste on thilke daye
That I was borne and make me fressh and gaye
And but thou doo to my noryce honoure
And to my chambre within my boure
And to my faders folke and his allyes
Thus seiste thou olde darel ful of lyes
And yet for oure prentys Iankyn
For his crispe here shynynge like golde fyne
And for he squireth me both vp and doun
Yet haste thou caught fals suspecioun
I wol him nat though thou were dede tomorowe
But telle me whie hidest thou with sorowe
Thy keyes of thy cheste awey from mee
It ys my gode as wel as thine pardee
What weneste thou make an ydiote of our dame
Nowe by the lorde that cleped ys seint Iame
Thou shalte nat but yf thou were wode
Be maister of my body and of my gode
That one thou shalte forgoone maugre thyn yien
What helpeth on me to enquyre and espyen
I trowe thou woldest lok me in thy cheste
Thou shuldeste sey wife goo where the leste
Take youre disporte leveth no tales
I knowe you for a trew wyf dame Ales
We love no man that taketh kepe or charge
Where that we goone we wil ben at oure large
Of alle men y blessed muste he bee
The wise Astrologen daun ꝓprotholomee
That seith this ꝓprouerbe in his almageste
Of almen his wisdome ys hieste
That retcheth nat whoo hath the worlde in honde
By this ꝓprouerbe thou shalte vnderstonde
Haue thou ynowe what dare thou rekke or care
Howe merely that other folkesse fare
For certes olde dotarde by youre leve
Ye shulle fynde queynt y nough at eve
He ys to grete a nygarde that wol werne
A man to light a candel at his lanterne
He shalle haue neuer the lesse light ꝑper/pardee
Haue thou ynough the dare nat pleyne thee
Thou seiste alsoo that we make vs gaye
Wit clothinge and with precious arraye
That it is peryl of our chastitee
And yet with sorowe thou muste enforce thee
And sey thise wordes in the appostels name
In abitte made with chastite and chame
Ye wommen shulde apꝑper/pareil you quod shee
And nat in tressed here and gaye perree
As perles ner with golde ner clothes ryche
After thy texte and after thy rubriche
I wol nat worch as much as ys a gnatte
Thou seideste this that I was like a catte
But who so wolde senge a cattes skynne
Thenne wolde the cat dwel in his ynne
And if the cattes skynne be slyke and gaye
She wol nat dwel in hous halfe a daye
And forth she wolle er eny day be dawed
To shewe hir skynne and goon on caterwawed
This is to sey yf I be gay sir shrewe
I wolle renne oute my borel for to shewe
Sir olde fole what helpeth the to espyen
Though thou pley argus with his hundred yen
To bee my warde cors as he can beste
In feith he shal nat kepe me but me leste
Yet couth I make his berde so mote I thee
Thou seideste eke that there ben thinges three
Which thinges trowblyn al this erthe
And that no wight may endure the ferth
O fyne sir shrewe ihu shorte thy life
Yet precheste thou and seiste an hate ful wife
Y rekned ys for one of thise myschaunces
Ben there non other resemblaunces
That ye may liken youre ꝑper/parables too
But if a sely wife ben one of thoo
Thou likenyste eke wommans love to hel
To bareyn londe there water may nat dwelle
Thou likenyste it alsoo too wilde fire
The more it brenneth the more it hath desire
To consume eủer/rey thinge that brent wol bee
Thou seiste that right as wormes shende a tree
Right soo a wife destroyeth hir husbonde
This knowe thise men that ben to wyues bonde
Lordinges right as ye han vnderstonde
Bare I sty myn olde husbonde on honde
That thus they seiden in hir drunkenesse
But al was fals but as I toke witnesse
Of Ienkyn and of myn elde alsoo
O lorde the pyne I didde hem and the woo
Ful giltelesse by goddes swete pyne
For as an hors I couth bothe byte and whyne
I coude pleyne and I was in the gilte
Or elles ofte tyme I had ben spilte
Whoo firste commeth to mylle firste grynte
I pleyned firste soo was oure werre stynte
They were ful gladde to excuse hem ful blyve
Of thinge whiche they neủer/re gilte in her lyve
Of wenches wolde I bere hem on honde
Whenne that for sike they might vnnethes stonde
Yet tikkeled I his herte for that hee
Wende I hadde of him soo grete chertee
I sware that al my walkyng oute by nyght
Was for to espye wenches that he dight
Vnder that coloure had I many a myrthe
For al such witte was youe vs in our byrthe
Disceyte wepynge spynnynge god hath yeve
To wommen kindely while that they may leve
And thus of oo thinge I auaunte me
Atte ende I had the better in eche degree
By sleighte or force or some maner thinge
As al contynuelle murmur or grucchinge
Namely in bed there had they myschaunce
There wolde I chide and done hem no plesaunce
I wolde no lenger in the bedde abyde
If I felte his arme ouer my syde
Til he had made his raunsome vn to me
Then wolde I suffre him done his nycetee
And therfore eủer/rey man this tale I telle
Wynne whoo soo may for al is for to selle
With empty honde men may none hawkes lure
For wynnynge wolde I al his luste endure
And make me a feyned appetyte
And yet in bacon had I neuer delyte
That made me that euer I wolde hem chide
For though the pope had sitten hem beside
I wolde nat spare hem at her owen borde
For by my trouth I quyt hem worde by worde
As helpe me verrey god omnipotente
Though I shulde right nowe make my testamente
I owe hem nat oo worde that nys quytte
I brought it soo aboute by my wytte
That they muste yeve it vpp as for the beste
O elles had we neuer ben in reste
For though he loked as a wode lioun
Yet shulde he faille of his conclusioun
Thenne wolde I sey gode lief take kepe
Howe mekely loketh wilkyn our shepe
Come nere my spouse lat me baa thy cheke
And haue a swete spiced conscience
Seth ye konne soo prech of pacience
That it is feire to haue a wife in pees
One of vs two muste bowen doutlees
And seth a man ys more resonable
Then womman ys ye muste be more suffrable
What eilleth you thus to gruch and grone
It ys for ye wolde haue my queinte alone
Whi take it al lo haue it here eủer/rey dele
Petre I shrewe you but ye love it wele
For if I wolde sel my bele chose
I couth walke as fressh as is the rose
But I wolle kepe it for youre owen toth
Ye ben to blame by god I sey you soth
Such maner wordes for to haue in honde
Nowe wol I speke of the ferth husbonde
My ferth husbonde was a reueloure
This is to seyne he had a paramoure
And I was yonge and ful of ragerye
Stoburne and stronge and ioly as a pye
Wel coude I daunce to an harpe smale
And singe ywis as eny nyghtingale
Whenne I had drunke a draught of swete wyne
Metellyus the foule cherle the swyne
That with a staffe berefte his wife hir life
For she dranke why though I had ben his wife
Ne shulde he nat haue daunted me from drinke
And after wyne on venus muste I thinke
For also siker as colde engendreth haylle
A lycorous mouth muste haue a licorous tail
Ye shulde ben as paciente and meke
In wommen vynolente is no diffence
This knowen lechours by experyence
But lorde criste whenne it remembreth me
Vpon my youthe and my Iolitee
It ticleth me aboute myn herte rote
Vnto this day it doth myn herte bote
That I haue had the werlde as in my tyme
But age allas that al wol envenyme
Hath me berefte my beaute and my pith
Let goo fare wel the deuyl goo there with
The floure ys goo there is nomore to tel
The brenne nowe as I beste can muste I sel
But yet to be right mery wol I fonde
Nowe wol I telle of my ferth husbonde
I sey I hadde in herte grete dispyte
That he of eny other hadde delyte
But he was quyt by god and by seint Ioce
I made him of the same wed a troce
Nat of my body in no foule manere
But certeinly I made folke suche chere
That in his owen grece I made him frye
For anger and for verrey Ielousy
By god in erth I was his purgatory
For which I hope his soul be in glory
For god it wote he sat ful ofte and songe
Whenne that his shoo ful bitterly him wronge
There was no wight saue god and hee it wiste
In many wise howe shortly I him twiste
He deide whenne I com from Ierusalem
And lieth grauen vnder the rode beme
Al is his toumbe nat soo curyous
As was the sepulcre of king daryus
Which that Appellus wrought soo solempnly
It is but waste to bury him pciouslye
Let him fare wel god yeve his soul reste
He is nowe graue and lith in his cheste
Nowe of my fyfte husbonde wol I tel
God lat his soule neuer come in hel
And yet was he to me the moste shrewe
That fele I on my ribbes al by rewe
And euir shal in to myne endinge daye
But in our bed he was soo fressh and gay /
And there with al wel couth he me glose
Whenne that he wolde haue my bele chose
That though he had me beten eủer/rey bone
He coude wynne my love sone anone
I trowe I loued him beste for that hee
Was of his love daungerous to mee
We wommen han if I shal nat lye
In this mater a wunder fantesye
Wayte what thinge we may nat lightly haue
There after wol we crye al day and crave
Forbede vs thinge and that desire wee
Prees on vs faste and
With daunger vtter we al oure chaffare
Prees atte marketh maketh dere ware
And grete chepe is holde at litle prys
This knoweth eủer/rey womman that is wys
My fifte husbonde god his soule blesse
Which that I toke for love and no rychesse
He sometyme was a clerke of oxenforde
And had lefte scole and went at home to borde
With my gossipp dwellinge in oure toun
God haue hir soule his name was alisoun
She knewe myn herte and eke my priuitee
Bet thenne our ꝑper/parissh preste soo muste I thee
To hir I wreyed my counseil alle
For had myn husbonde pissed on a wal
Or doone a thinge that shulde haue coste his life
To hir and to another worthy wyf
And to my nece which I loued wel
I wolde haue tolde his counseil eủer/reydele
And soo I didde ful ofte god yt wote
That made his face ofte rede and hote
For v̉er/reey shame and blamed him selfe for þᵗat he
Had tolde to me so muche priuite
And so befel that ones in a lente
Soo often tymes I to my gossipp wente
For euir yet I loued to bee gaye
And for to walke in march april and maye
From hous to hous to here sundry tales
That Iankyn and my gossipp dame Ales
And I me selfe in to the feldes wente
Myn husbonde was at londoıı̄un al the lente
I had the better leyser for to pleye
And for to see and eke for to preye
I lusty fole what wiste I where my grace
Was shapen for to ben or in what place
There fore I made my visitacions
To vigilles and to ꝓprocessions
To prechinge eke and to thise pilgrymages
To pleyes of myracles and of maryages
And wered vpon my gay scarlet gytes
Thise wormes ner thise mothes ne thise mytes
Vpon my ꝑper/parel fret hem neuer a dele
And woste thou whie for they were vsed wele
Nowe wolle I telle forth what happed me
I sey that in the feldes walked wee
Til trewly we had such daliaunce
This clerke and I that of my pʳueyaunce
I spake to him and seid howe that hee
If I were wydowe shulde wedden me
For certeinly I sey for no bobaunce
Yet was I neuer withoute pʳueyaunce
Of maryage ne of other thinges eke
I holde a mous herte nat worth a leke
That hath but one hole to sterte too
And if that feyl thenne ys al I doo
But nowe sir let me see what shal I seyn
A by god I haue my tale ageyne
Whenne my ferth husbonde was on bere
I wepte algate and made sory chere
As wifes muste for yt ys vsage
And with my kerchiefe coủer/reed my visage
But for I was ꝓprouyded of a make
I wepte but smal and that I vndertake
To chirch was myn husbonde born on morowe
With neighburghes that for him made sorowe
And Iankyn our clerke was one of thoo
As helpe me god whenne I sawe him goo
After the bere me thought he had a peire
Of legges and of fete soo clene and feire
That al myn herte I yaue in to his holde
He was I trowe twenty winter olde
And I was fourty if I shal sey sothe
But yet I hadde alwey a coltes tothe
Gat tothed was I and that become me wele
I had a prynte of seint venus seale
As helpe me god I was a lusty one
And feire and riche and yonge ⁊and wel begone
And truly as myn husbonde tolde me
I had the beste quonyam that myght bee
Myn ascendente was taure and mars ther ynne
Allas Allas that euer love was synne
I folowed ay myn inclynacioune
Be v̉er/retue of my constellacioune
That made me I coude nat with drawe
My chambre of venus from a gode felawe
What shal I sey but at the monthes ende
This ioly clerke that was soo gentil ⁊and hende
Hath wedded me with grete solempnitee
And to him yave I al the londe and fee
That euer me was yeve there before
But afterwarde I repented me ful sore
He nolde suffre no thinge of my leste
By god he smote me ones in the breste
For that I rente out of his boke a lefe
That of that stroke myn eres wexen defe
Stuburne I was as eny leonesse
And of myn age a verrey iangelresse
And walke I wolde as I had doon beforne
From hous to hous al though he had it sworne
For whiche often tymes wolde he preche
And me olde romayne gestes teche
Howe he Simplicius gallus loste his wife
And hi forsoke for terme of al his life
Nat but for openhede he hir saye
Lokinge oute at his dore vpon a day
And other romaynes tolde he me by name
That for his wife was at a somers game
Withoute his wetinge he forsoke hir eke
And he wolde here vpon his bible seke
That ilke prouerbe of ecclesiaste
Where he forbedeth and commaundeth faste
Man shal nat suffre his wife to royl aboute
Thenne wolde he seyn right thus wᵗithouten doute
Whoo so beldeth al his hous of salous
And pricketh his blinde hors ouir the falowes
And suffreth his wife for to goo seken halowes
Is worthy to ben honged on the galowes
But al for nought I set nat an hawe
Of his ꝓprouerbe ner of his olde sawe
Neither I wolde of hym corrected bee
I hate him that my vices telleth mee
Lorde soo doth moo god wote thenne .I.
This made him wode al vtterlye
I nolde forbere him in the cas
Nowe wol I sey you by seint thomas
Why that I rente out of his booke a lefe
For which he smote me that I was defe
He had a booke that gladly night and day
For his disporte he wolde rede alway
He cleped it valerye and theofaste
And with that boke he lough alwey ful faste
And eke there was some tyme a clerke in rome
A cardinal that hight seint Ierome
That made a boke ayeinste Iouynyan
In which boke eke there was tertulan
Crisippus trotula and helowys
That was Abbesse nat fer from parys
And eke the parables of salamon
Ouydes arte and bokes many one
And al thise were bounden in one volume
And eủer/rey night and day was his custome
Whenne tyme was of vacacioun
From other worldly occupacioun
To reden in this boke of wicked wyues
He knewe of hem moo legendes and yues
Thenne ben of gode wyues in the bible
For trusteth wel it is an ympossible
That eny clerke wol speke eny gode of wyues
But if it bee of holy seintes lyues
Ne of other wommen neuir the moo
Who peinteth the lioun tel me whoo
By god if wommen had writen storyes
As han with her oratoryes
They wolde haue writen of men more wickednesse
Thenne alle the marke of Adam may redresse
The children of mecury and of venus
But in hir worchinge ful contraryous
Mercury loueth wisdome and science
And venus loueth ryotte and dispence
And for their diuers disposicioune
Eche failleth in others exaltacioune
And thus god wote mercury ys desolate
And pisses were venus
And venus failleth there mercury ys reysed
Therfore no womman of no clerke ys preised
The clerke whenne he is olde and may nat doo
Of venus werkes nat worth his olde shoo
Thenne sitteth he doun and writeth in his dotage
That wommen conne nat kepe her maryage
But nowe to pʳpoos whie I tolde thee
That I was beten for a boke pardee
Vpon a night Iankyn that was oure sire
Red on his booke as he sat by the fire
Of eve firste that for hir wickednesse
Was al mankinde brought to wrecchednesse
Thoo radde he howe that Sampson loste his heres
Slepinge his lemman kytte with hir sheres
Thoo with tresoun loste he bothe his yien
Thoo radde he me if I shal nat lyen
Of hercules and of his dyanyre
That caused him to sette him self on fyre
Naught forgate he the care and the woo
That Socrates had with his wyues twoo
Howe panpipa kiste pisse vpon his hede
This sely man satte stylle as he were dede
He wyped his hede nomore durste he seyne
But after thunder commeth anone a reyne
Of pasipha that was the quene of Crete
For shrewdenesse him thought the tale swete
Fye speke nomore it ys a grisely thinge
Off horryble luste and her likinge
Of Clitermystra for her lecherye
That falsly made hir husbonde for to dye
That one for loue that other was for hate
Lyuia hir husbonde on an even late
Enpoysened for that she was his foo
Lucia licorous loued hir husbonde soo
That for he shulde alwey vpon hir thinke
She yaue him suche a maner love drinke
That he was dede er yt was by the morowe
And thus Algates husbondes hadden sorowe
Thanne tolde he me howe one latumyus
Compleyned to his felawe arryus
That in his garden growed such a tree
On which he seide that his wyuez three
Honged hem selfe for yre despitous
O leve brother quod this arryus
Yeve me a plante of that blissed tree
And in my garden planted shal yt bee
Of latter dedes of wyues hath he redde
That some han slayne hir husbondes in her bedde
And let her lechours dight hem al the nyght
While the cors lay in the flore vp righte
And some han dryuen nailles in the brayne
While that they slepe and thus they han hem slayne
Some han yeve hem poyson in her drinke
He spake more harme then hert may bethinke
And there with al he knewe mo prouerbes
Thenne in the worlde growen gresse or erbes
Bet ys quod he thine habitacioune
Bet with a lioun or a foule dragoune
Thenne with a womman vsant for to chide
Bet ys quod he hygh in the roofe to abyde
Thenne with a wicked womman doun in the hous
They ben soo wicked and contraryous
They haten that her husbondes louen aye
He seid a womman caste hir shame a waye
Whenne she caste of hir smoke and forther moo
A feire womman but she be chaste alsoo
Is like a golde rynge in a sowes noos
Whoo wolde wene or whoo wolde suppoos
The woo that in myn herte was and pyne
And whenne I sawe he wolde neuir fyne
To reden on this cursed booke al nyght
Al sodeinly thre leves haue I plight
Out of his boke right as he radde and eke
I with my fiste soo toke him on the cheke
That in oure fire he fil bakwarde anone
And he sterte vpp as doth a wode lyoune
And with his fiste he smote me on the hede
That in the flore I lay as I were dede
And whenne he sawe howe stille that I laye
He was a gaste and wolde haue fled awaye
Til atte laste oute of my swoun I breyde
O haste thou slayne me fals thefe she seyde
And for my love thus haste thou murthered me
Or I be dede yet wol I kissen thee
And ner he come and kneled feire a doun
And seide dere suster Alisoun
As helpe me god I shal the neuer smyte
That I haue doone it was the selfe to wyte
Foryeve it me that I the beseke
And yet efte sones I smote him on the cheke
And seide thefe thus muche I me awreke
Nowe wol I dey I may no lenger speke
But at the laste with much care and woo
Ful wele we fil at a corde bitwix vs twoo
He yaue me al the bridel in myn honde
To haue the gouernaunce of hous and londe
And of his tunge and of his honde alsoo
And made him brenne his boke anone right thoo
And whenne I hadde gete him vntoo mee
By maistry and al the soủer/reeyntee
And that he seid myn owen trewe wife
Doo as the liste terme of al thy life
Kepe myne honoure and kepe myne estate
After that daye we hadde neuer debate
God helpe me soo I was to him as kinde
As eny wife from denmarke in to ynde
And als trewe was he alsoo to mee
I pray to god that sitte in maiestee
So blisse his soule for his mercy dere
Nowe wol I sey my tale yf ye wil here
The frere lough whenne he had herd al this
Nowe dame quod he soo haue I ioy or blis
This is a longe preamble of a tale
And whenne the sumpnoure herde the frere gale
Owhen .the sumpnoure by goddes armes twoo
A frere wol entermeten euermoo
Loo gode men a flye and a frere
Wollen fallen in euery dissh and mater
What spekeste thou of preambulacioune
What amble or trotte or pees or goo sit a doune
Thou letteste oure desporte in this manere
Ye wolte thou soo sir sumpnoure quod the frere
Nowe by my feith I shal er that I goo
Tel of a sumpnoure suche a tale or twoo
That al the folke shal laughen in this place /
Nowe elles frere I wol beshrewe thy face
Quod this sumpnoure and I beshrewe me
But if that I tel tales twoo or three
Of freres er I come to sydyngburne
That I shal make thyne herte soo to murne
For wel I wote thy pacience ys goone
Oure hooste cryed pees and that anone
And seid let the womman tel hir tale
Ye fare as folke that drunken ben of ale
Gode dame tel youre tale and that is beste
Al redy sir quod she right as ye leste
If I haue licence of this worthy frere
Yis dame quod he tel forth and I wol here

div.l: (base) Hadde in his hous a lusty Bachiler
(base) That on a day cam ridyng fro Ryuer
(base) And happed that allone as he was born
(base) He say a mayde walkynge hym biforn
(base) Of which mayde anoon maugree hir hed
(base) By verray force he rafte hir maydenhed
(base) For which oppressioun was swich clamour
(base) And swich pursuyte vnto the kyng Arthour
(base) That dampned was this knyght for to be deed
(base) By cours of lawe and sholde han lost his heed
(base) Par auenture swich was the Statut tho
(base) But that the queene and othere ladyes mo
(base) So longe preyden the kyng of grace
(base) Til he his lyf hym graunted in the place
(base) And yaf hym to the queene al at hir wille
(base) To chese wheither she wolde hym saue or spille
(base) The queen thanked þe kyng wiþ al hir might
(base) And after this thus spak she to the knyght
(base) Whan that she saw hir tyme vpon a day
(base) Thow standest yet quod she in swich array
(base) That of thy lyf yet hastow no suretee
(base) I graunte thee lyf if thow kanst tellen me
(base) What thyng is it that wommen moost desiren
(base) Be war and keep thy nekke boon from Iren
(base) And if thow kanst nat tellen me anon
(base) Yet wol I yeue thee leue for to gon
(base) A twelf monthe and a day to seche and lere
(base) An answere suffisant in this matere
(base) And seuretee wol I han er that thow pace
(base) Thy body for to yelden in this place
(base) Wo was this knyght and sorwefully he siketh
(base) But what he may nat doon al as hym liketh
(base) And atte laste he chees hym for to wende
