¶ Theire meke praier and their meke chere
Made the marques herte haue pitee
Ye willeth quoth he myn own peple dere
Doo that I neuir erste thought streyn me
I me reioysed of my libertee
That selde tyme ys founde in maryage
There as was free thing ben in seruage
¶ But natheles I see youre trewe entente
And truste vpon youre wit and haue doo aye
Where fore of my fre will I wol assente
To wedde me as sone as euir I may
But there as ye han ꝓprofred me to day
To chese me a wife I wol relese
That choys and pray you of that ꝓprofre rese
¶ For god wote that childre ofte ben
Vnlike her worthy elders hem before
Bounte comth ofte of god and nat of strene
Of which they ben engendred and ybore
I truste in goddes bountee and there fore
My mariage and myn estate and reste
Ihn I betake he may doo as him leste
¶ Let me allone in chesinge of my wife
That charge vpon my bak I wol endure
But I you pry and charge vpon your life
That what wife I take ye me ensure
To worshipp hir while hir life may dure
In worde and werke both here and eủer/rey where
As she an emꝑper/parours doughter were
¶ And ferthermore ye shul swere that ye
Ayeinste my choys shal neuer grutch ner stryve
For seth I haue forgone my libertee
At youre requeste as euir̉er/re mote I thryve
There as myn herte is sette there wol I wyne
And but ye wil assente in swich maner
I pray you speke no more of this mater
¶ With hertely wile they sworen and assente
To al this thinge there seid no wight nay
Besechinge him of grace er that he wente
That he wolde graunte hem a certein day
Of his spousail as sone as euir he may
For yet the peple some were adradde
Leste that the marques no wif wolde wedde
¶ He gᵃunted hem a day swiche as him leste
On which he wolde ben wedded sikerly
And seid he didde al this at hir requeste
And with humble entrete buxumly
Knel on hi knees full reủer/reently
Hym then thnked al and thus they han an ende
Of hir enent and home ayein hey wende
¶ And there vpon he his officers
Commaundeth for the feste to puruey
And to his pduey knightes and squires
Such charge yave as liste on hem leye
And they to his commaundement obey
And eche of hem doth his diligence
To done to the feste grete reuerence
¶ Nat fer from that paleys honoureable
Where as this marques shope his maryage
There stode a smal thrope ful delectable
In which the poıı̄unr folke of that village
Hadden her bestes and her herbergage
And of her laboure toke their sustenaunce
After that the erth yave hem abundaunce
¶ Amonge thise poıı̄une folke dwelte a man
What that was holde poıı̄uneste of hem al
But high god some tyme senden can
His grace in too a litel Ox . stall
Iamele of that thrope men him cal
A doughter he has feire ynough to sight
And Gresilde this younge mayden hight
¶ But for to speke of vertuous beautee
Thenne was she one the feirese vnder sonne
Ful poıı̄unely vp fustred was shee
No licouresnesse was thurgh hir luste yronne
Ful ofter of the wel thenne of the tonne
She dranke and for she wolde vertue plese
She knewe wel laboure but no ydel ease
¶ But through this maide tender were of age
Yet in the breste of hir virginitee
There was enclosed ripe and sad corage
And iningrete reuerence and grete cheritee
Hir olde poıı̄une fader fustred shee
A fewe shepe spynnynge on the felde she kepte
For she woulde nat ben ydel til she slepte
¶ And whenne she homwarde come she wolde bringe
Wortes and herbes tymes ful ofte
Which she shrad and seeth for hir lyuynge
And made hir bed ful harde and nothing softe
And eủer/ree she kepte hir faders life on lofte
With eủer/rey obeysaunce and diligence
That child may doon to fadres reuerence
Vp on Grisilde this poure creature
Ful ofte sithe this Markys sette his eye
As he on huntyng rood per auenture
And whan it fil that he myghte hir espie
He noght wit wantowne lookyng of folye
Hise eyen caste on hir but in sad wyse
Vp on hir cheere he wolde hym ofte auyse
Commendynge in his herte hir wommanhede
And eek hir vertu passyng any wight
Of so yong age as wel in cheere as dede
For thogh the peple hath no greet insight
In vertue he considered ful right
Hir bountee and disposed that he wolde
Wedde hir oonly if euere he wedden sholde
The day of weddyng cam but no wight kan
Telle what womman that it sholde be
For which merueille wondred many a man
And seyden whan they were in priuetee
Wol nat oure lord yet leue his vanytee
Wol he nat wedde allas the while
Why wol he thus hym self and vs bigyle
But nathelees this Markys hath doon make
Of gemmes set in gold and in Asure
Broches and rynges for Grisildis sake
And of hir clothyng took he the mesure
Of a mayde lyk to hir stature
And eek of othere aournementes alle
That vn to swich a weddyng sholde falle
The tyme of vndren of the same day
Approcheth that this weddyng sholde be
And al the palays put was in array
Bothe halle and chambres ech in his degree
Houses of office stuffed with plentee
Ther maystow seen of deynteuous vitaille
That may be founde as fer as last Ytaille
This Roial Markys richeliche arrayed
Lordes and ladys in his compaignye
The whiche that to the feste were yprayed
And of his retenue the Bachilrye
With many a sown of sondry melodye
Vn to the village of the which I tolde
In this array the righte wey han holde
Grisilde of this god woot ful Innocent
That for hir shapen was al this array
To fecchen water at a welle is went
And cometh hom as soone as euer she may
For wel she hadde herd seyd that thilke day
The Markys sholde wedde and if she myghte
She wolde fayn han seyn som of that sighte
She thoghte I wole with othere maydens stonde
That been my felawes in oure dore and se
The Markisesse and therfore wol I fonde
To doon at hom as soone as it may be
The labour which that longeth vn to me
And thanne I may at leyser hir biholde
Yf she this wey vn to the Castel holde
And as she wolde ouer the thresshfold gon
The Markys cam and gan hir for to calle
And she sette doun hir water pot anon
Bisyde the thresshfold in an Oxes Stalle
And doun vp on hir knees she gan to falle
Thought she sayde but let him alon
And with sad contenance kneleth stille
Til she hadde herd what was the lordes wille
This thoghtful Markys spak vn to this mayde
Ful sobrely and seyde in this manere
Where is youre fader o Grisildis he sayde
And she with reuerence in humble cheere
Answerde lord he is al redy heere
And she goth with outen lenger lette
And to the Markys she hir fader fette
He by the hand than took this olde man
And seyde thus whan he hym hadde asyde
Ianicula I neither may ne kan
Lenger the plesance of myn herte hyde
If that thow vouche sauf what so bityde
Thy doughter wole I take er that I wende
As for my wife vnto my lyues ende
¶ Thou loueste me I wote it wel certein
And erte my feithfulle liege man bore
And al that liketh me I dare wel seyn
It liketh the and specilly therefore
Telle me that pointe that I haue seide before
If that thou wilte vn to that pʳpoos drawe
To take me as for thy sonne in lawe
¶ The sodeyn cas this man astonyed soo
The rede he wex abasshed and al quakinge
He stede vnneth ne seide he wordes moo
But onely thus lorde quod he my willinge
Is as ye wil nat ayeinste your liking
I wole noo thinge ye ben my lorde so dere
Right as you luste goủer/reneth this matere
¶ Thenne wole I doo thus quod the markes softely
That in to the chamber I . and thou and she
Haue a collacion and woste thou whye
For I wole aske hir yf hir wil bee
To be my wife and reule hir after me
And al this she shal doone in thy psence
I wol nat speke out of thine audience
¶ And in the chamber while they were aboute
Hir tretys which ye shalle after here
The peple come in to the hous withoute
And wondred in howe honeste manere
And ententifely she kept hir fader dere
But vtterly Gresilde wundre might
For neuer erste sawe she such a sight
¶ No wunder though she were astonyed
To see soo grete a geste come to that place
She was neủer/rere to such gestes woned
For which she loked with ful pale face
But shortly on this mater for to trace
this were the wordes that this markes seide
Tho this benygne vey feithfull maide
¶ Gresilde he siede ye shal wel vnderstonde
It lyketh vnto youre fader and to me
That I you wedde and eke it may soo stonde
As I suppose ye wille that it so bee
But this demaunde I aske firste quod he
That seth it shal be done in hasty wife
Wol ye assente or wol ye yon avise
¶ I sey thus bee ye redy with gode herte
To al my luste and that I frely may
As me beste thenk doo you laugh or smerte
And ye neuir to grutche night ne day
And eke whenn I sey yee . ye sey nat nay
Neither by worde ner frowarde countenaunce
Swere this and here I swere oure alliaunce
¶ Wondreinge vpon this worde quaking for drede
She sied lorde . indigne and vnworthy
Am I to thilke worshipp that ye me bede
But right as ye wil you selfe so wol I .
And I swere that neuer willingly
In werke ne thought I wil you disobey
For to be dede though me be loth to dey
¶ This is ynough Gresilde myn quod he
And forth he goth with a sober chere
Out atte the dore and after him com she
And to the peple he seid in this manere
This is my wife quod he that stondeth here
Honoureth hir and loueth hir I you pray
Who so loueth me there ys nomore to sey
¶ And for nothinge of hir olde gere
Shulde to his hous be ladde
Wommen anone despoilled hem right there
Of which the ladies were nat right gladde
To handel her clother in which she was clad
But nathelesse this maide bright of hewe
From hede to gote they clothed han al newe
¶ Her heres han they kembed that lay vntressed
Ful rudely with her gingres smale
And a croun on hir hede they han dressed
And set it ful of ouches grete and smale
Of hir array what shal I make a tale
Vnneth the peple hir knewe for hir feirnesse
Whenne tᵃsfoᵘurmed she was in swiche rychesse
¶ This markes hath hir spowsed with a ringe
Brought for the same cause and thenne her sette
Vpon an hors snowe white and amblinge
And to his paleys er he lenger lette
With ioyful peple that he ladde and mette
Conueyed hir and thus the day they spende
In reuel tille the sonne ganne descende
¶ And shortly on this tale for to chace
I sey that to this newe marquesse
God hath sent such fauoure of his grace
That itte semed nat by liklynesse
that she was borne and fed in rudenesse
As in a cote or in an ox stalle
But norisshed in an emꝑper/paroures halle
¶ To eủer/rey wight she woxen is soo dere
And worshipful . that folke there she was bore
And from hir birthe knewe hir from yere to yere
Vnnethes trowed they but durste haue swore
That to Ianicle of which I spake before
She doughter ne were but as by conIecture
Hem thought she was another creature
¶ For that euir vertuous was shee
She was encresed in such excellence
Of thewes sette in hir of bountee
And so discrete and feire of elloquence
Soo bnynge and digne of reủer/reence
And couth the peples hertes soo enbrace
That eche hir loued that loked in hir face
¶ Nat onley of Salusens in the toun
Publisshed was the bounte of hir name
But eke beside in many a regioun
If one sied wele another sied the same
So spradde of hir bounte the fame
That men and and wommen both yong and olde
Good to Saluce hir fer to beholde
¶ This Waulter lowely nay but ryally
Weddeth with fortunes honestee
And leueth in goddes pees al easely
At home and outwarde grace had hee
And for he sawe vnder lowe degree
Was ofte vertue hidde the peple him helde
Aprudent man and that ys sene ful selde
¶ Nat onely Gresilde this thurgh hir witte
Coude al the fette of wifely homelynesse
But eke whenne the cas required ytte
The comune ꝓproite coude she redresse
Ther nas discorde rancoure ner heuynesse
In al the londe that she ne coude appese
And bringe hem al wifely in reste and ease
¶ Though that hir husbonde pent were or none
If gentilmen or other of hir Cuntree
Were wroth she couth bring hem at one
Soo wise and ripe wordes had shee
And iuggemente of grete equite
that she from heuyn was come as men wende
Peple to save and eủer/rey wronge to amende
¶ Nat longe tyme after that this Gresilde
Was wedded she a daughter had ybore
Al hadde she leuer hane borne a knave childe
Glad was the marques and his folke therefore
For though a maiden childe come before
She may to a knave childe atteyne
By liklyhede seth she ys nat bareyne
¶ Therefore as it falleth tymes moo
Whenne this childe hath sowked but a throwe
This marques in his herte longeth soo
To tempte his wife hir sadnesse for to knowe
That he ne might from his herte throwe
This meueillous desire his wife to assay
Causeles god wote hir to affray
¶ For he assayed hir ynough before
And founde hir euir gode what nedth itte
Hir for to turment alwey more and more
Thogh som men preyse it for a subtil wit
But as for me I seye that yuele it sit
Tassaye a wyf whan that it is no nede
And putten hir in angwyssh and in drede
For which this Markys wroghte in this manere
He cam allone a nyght ther as she lay
With steerne face and with ful trouble cheere
And seyde thus Grisilde quod he that day
That I yow took out of your poure array
And putte yow in estat of heigh noblesse
Ye haue nat that forgeten as I gesse
I seye Grisilde this persent dignitee
In which that I haue put yow as I trowe
Maketh yow nat foryetful for to be
That I yow took in poure estat ful lowe
For any wele ye mote your seluen knowe
Tak hede of euery word that I yow seye
Ther is no wight that hereth it but we tweye
Ye woot your self wel how that ye cam heere
In to this hous it is nat longe ago
And thogh to me that ye be lief and deere
Vnto my gentils ye be no thyng so
They seyn to hem it is greet shame and wo
For to be subgitz and been in seruage
To thee that born art of a smal village
And namely sith thy doghter was ybore
Thise wordes han they spoken doutelees
But I desire as I haue doon bifore
To lyue my lyf with hem in reste and pees
I may nat in this cas be recchelees
I moot doon with thy doghter for the beste
Nat as I wolde but as my peple leste
And yet god woot this is ful looth to me
But nathelees with outen your wityng
I wol nat doon but this wol I quod he
That ye to me assente as in this thyng
Shewe now youre pacience in your wirkyng
As we accorded was at ᵗe begynnyng
That ye me highte and swore in yone village
By youre bihest a fore youre fader sage
That day that maked was oure mariage
Whan she hadde herd al this she noght ameued
Neither in word or cheere or contenance
For as it semed she was nat agreued
She seyde lord al lith in your plesance
My child and I with hertly obeisance
Been youres al and ye mowe saue or spille
Youre owene thyng werketh after your wille
Ther may no thyng god so my soule saue
Liken to yow that may displesen me
Ne I ne desire no thyng for to haue
Ne drede for to lese saue oonly thee vel ye
This wyl is in myn herte and ay shal be
No lengthe of tyme or deth may this deface
Ne chaunge my corage to oother place
Glad was this Markys of hir answeryng
But yet he feyned as he were nat so
Al drery was his cheere and his lookyng
Whan that he sholde out of the chambre go
Soone after this a furlang wey or two
He pryuely hath told al his entente
Vn to a man and to his wyf hym sente
A
A maner sergeant was this priuee man
The which that feithful ofte he founden hadde
In thynges grete and eek swich folk wel kan
Doon execucioun in thynges badde
The lord knew wel that he m loued and dradde
And whan this sergeant wiste his lordes wille
In to the chambre he stalked hym ful stille
Madame he seyde ye mote foryeue it me
Thogh I do thyng to which I am constreyned
Ye ben so wys that ful wel knowe ye
That lordes hestes mowe nat ben yfeyned
They mowe wel been biwailled or compleyned
But men mote nede vn to hir lust obeye
And so wol I ther is namoore to seye
This child I am comaunded for to take
And spak namoore but out the child he hente
Despitously and gan a chere make
As he wolde haue slayn it er he wente
Gresilde moste al suffre and al consente
And as a lambe she sitteth meke and stil
And let this cruel sergeannte doon his wil
¶ Suspecte was the fame of this manne
Suspecte his face suspecte his worde also
For hir doughter that she loued soo
She wende he wolde haue slayn it right thoo
But natheles she neither wpet ner siked
Comfourmyng hir to that the marques liked
¶ But at the laste speke she beganne
And mekely to the sergeaunt she praide
Soo as he was a worthy gentilman
That she might kiss his childe er that it deide
And in hir barme this litle childe she leide
With ful sad face and gan the childe to blisse
And lulled it and after ganne it kisse
¶ And thus she seide in hir benygne voys
Farewel my childe i shal the neuer see
But seth I haue marked the with the croys
Of thilke fader blessed mote thon bee
That for vs deide vpon the rode tree
Thy soule litel childe I him betake
For this night shalte thou dyen for my sake
¶ I trowe that to a noryce in this cas
It had ben harde this routh for to see
Wel might a moder then cry allas
But nathelesse so sad steadfaste was shee
That she endured al aduersitee
And to the sergeaunte mekely she seid
Haue here ageine my little yonge maide
¶ And goth nowe quod she and doo my lordes heste
But oo thing wolde I pᵃy you of youre grace
That but my lorde forbede you atte leste
uryeth this little body in some place
That no bestes ner briddes it arrace
But he noo worde to purpos wolde sey
But toke the childe and went vpon his wey
¶ This sergeaunte come to the lorde agein
And of Gresildes wordes and hir chere
He tolde him point to pointe short and plein
And him presented with his doughter dere
Some what this lord had routh on his manere
But nathelesse thi pʳpoos hielde he stille
As lordes done whenne they wil haue her wille
¶ And thenne he bad this sergeaunte priuely
He shulde stil softe this childe wynde and wrapp
With al circumstanunces tenderlye
And cary in a cofer or in a lapp
And vp peyne of his hede of to swapp
No man shulde knowe of his entente
Ne whennes it come ne whedir it wente
¶ But at Boleyn at his suster dere
That thenne of pauy was countesse
He shulde hir take and shew hir this matere
Besechinge hir to doone hir besynesse
This childe to fuster in al gladnesse
And whos childe that is was he bad hir hide
From eủer/rery wight for aught that may be tide
¶ this sergeaunte goth and hath fulfilled this thing
But to this marques nowe return wee
For nowe goth he ful ofte ymagenynge
If by his wife he might see
Or by her wordes ꝑper/parceyue that shee
Were chaunged but he coude neuer finde
But euer in one elyke sadde and kinde
¶ As glade as humble as besy in seruice
And eke in love as she was wonte to bee
Was she to him in eủer/rey maner wise
Ner of hir doughter oo worde spake shee
Noon accident for none aduersitee
Was seen in hir ne neuir hir doughters name
Neempned she in ernest ner is game
¶ In this estat passed ben . iiii . yere
Er she with childe was but as god wolde
A knaue child she bar by this Walter
Ful gracious and fair for to biholde
And whan that folk it to his fader tolde
Nat oonly he but al his contree merye
Was for this child and god they thanke and herye
Whan it was two yeer old and fro the brest
Departed of his Norice on a day
This Markys caughte yet another lest
To tempte his wyf yet ofter if he may
O nedelees was she tempted in assay
But wedded men ne knowe no mesure
Whan that they fynde a pacient creature
Wyf quod this Markys ye han herd er this
My peple sikly berth this mariage
And namely sith my sone yborn is
Now is it worse than euere in al oure age
The murmur sleeth myn herte and my corage
For to myne erys comth the voys so smerte
That it wel neigh destroyed hath myn herte
Now sey they thus whan Walter is agon
Thanne shal the blood of Ianycle succede
And been oure lord for oother haue we noon
Swiche wordes seith my peple out of drede
Wel oghte I of swich murmur taken hede
For certeinly I drede swich sentence
Though they nat pleyn speke in myn audience
I wolde lyue in pees if that I myghte
Wherfore I am disposed outrely
As I his suster serued by nyghte
Right so thenke I to serue hym priuely
This warne I yow that ye nat sodeynly
Out of your self for no wo sholde outraye
Beth pacient and ther of I yow praye
I haue quod she seyd thus and euere shal
I wol no thyng ne nyl no thyng certeyn
But as yow list noght greueth me at al
Thogh that my doghter and my sone be sleyn
At youre comandement this is to seyn
I haue nat had no part of children tweyne
But first siknesse and after wo and peyne
Ye ben oure lord dooth with your owene thyng
Right as yow list axeth no reed of me
For as I lefte at hom al my clothyng
Whan I first cam to yow right so quod she
Lefte I my wyl and al my libertee
And took youre clothyng wher fore I yow preye
Dooth your plesance I wol youre lust obeye
And certes if I hadde prescience
Youre wyl to knowe er ye your lust me tolde
I wolde it doon with outen necligence
But now I woot youre lust and what ye wolde
Al your plesance ferm and stable I holde
For wiste I that my deeth wolde doon yow ese
Right gladly wolde I dyen yow to plese
Deeth may nat make no comparisoun
Vn to youre loue and whan this Markys say
The constance of his wyf he caste adoun
Hise eyen two and wondreth that she may
In pacience suffre al this array
And forth he goth with drery contenance
But to his herte it was ful gret plesance
This vggly XXgeant in the same wyse
That he hir doghter caughte right so he
Or worse if men worse kan deuyse
Hath hent hir sone that ful was of beautee
And euere in oon so pacient was she
That she no cheere made of heuynesse
But kiste hir sone and after gan it blesse
Saue this she prayde hym that if he myghte
Hir litel sone he wolde in erthe graue
His tendre lymes delicat to sighte
Fro foweles and fro bestes hem to saue
But she noon answere of hym myghte haue
He wente his wey as hym no thyng roghte
But to Boloigne he tendrely it broghte
¶ This marques wondreth eủer/ree lenger the more
Vpon hir patience and if that hhee
Ne had sothely known there before
That ꝑper/parfitely hir children loued shee
He wolde houe wende therof some subtiltee
And of malice or cruel corage
That she had suffred this with sad visage
¶ But wel he knewe that next him self certein
She loued hir children beste in eủer/rey wise
But nowe of wommen wolde I aske feyn
If this assayes might nat suffise
What coude a sturdy husbonde more devise
To prove hir wifhode and hir stedfastenesse
And be contynuynge in sturdynesse
¶ But there be folke of swich condicioun
that whnne they han a certein pʳpoos take
They can nat stinte of their entencioun
But as they were bounded to a stake
They wille nat of their pʳpoos slake
Right soo this marques fully hat pʳposed
To tempte his wife as was furste disposed
¶ He wayteth if by worde or countenaunce
if she to him was chaunged of corage
But neủer/ree coude he finden variaunce
She was euir in hert and in visage
And euir the ferther that she was in age
The more truer if it were possible
She was to him in love and more penyble
¶ For which it semeth thus that of hem twoo
There was but oo wil for was was his luste
The same luste was hir plesaunce alsoo
And god be thanked al fil for the beste
She shewed wel for no worldly vnreste
A wif as of hir selfe no thing shulde
Willen in effecte but as hir husbonde wolde
¶ The sclaunder of waulter ofte wyde spradde
That of a cruelly herte wickedly
For he a pouʳe womman wedde hadde
Hadde murdred bothe his children peiuely
Such murmur was amonge hem comunly
Noo wonder for vn to the peples ere
There come no worde but that they murdred were
¶ For swiche were of his peple there before
Had loued him wele desclaunderer of his name
Made hem that they hated him therfore
To ben a murderer ys an hateful name
But nathelesse for erneste ne for game
he of his crueltee wolde nat stente
To tempte his wife was al his entente
¶ Whenne this doughter xii yere was of age
He to the courte of rome in subtil wise
Enfoᵘurmed of his wiffe sent his message
Cammaunded him such bulles to deuyse
As to his cruel pʳpoos may suffise
Howe that the pope for his peples reste
Bad him wedde another if him leste
¶ I sey they bad he shulde counterfete
The popes bulles makinge mencioun
That he hath leve his furste wife to lete
As by the popes dispensacioun
to stynte rancoure and discencioun
Betwix his peple and him thus spak the bul
The which they han publisshed atte ful
¶ The rude peple as it no wunder ys
Wende ful wel it had be right soo
But thus tidinges come to Gresildes
I deme that her hert was ful woo
But she elike sad foreủer/remoo
Disposed was this humble creature
The aduersitee of forune to endure
¶ Abydinge euir his luste and his plesaunce
To whom she was yonen herte and al
As to hir verrey worldly suffisaunce
But certeinly forth this story tel I shal
This marques writen hath in especial
A letter in which he shewed hath his entente
And sekerly to Boleyne he it sente .
¶ To the erle of pauk which that hadde soo
Wedded his suster he prayed specially
To bringe him ayein his children twoo
In honoureable estate al openly
But oo thinge he him prayed vtterly
That he to no wight though men wolde enquere
Shulde nat tellen whos childeren they were
¶ But sey that the maide shulde wedded bee
Vn to the marques of Saluce anone
And as the erle was prayed soo didde hee
For at a day sette he on his wey is gone
Towarde Saluce and lordes many one
In rich array this mayde forth to guyde
Her yonge brother rydinge by her syde
¶ Arrayed was towarde this maryage
This maide fresshly ful of gemmes clere
Hir brother that seuen yere was of age
Arrayed eke was fresshly on his manere
And in grete noblesse and gladde chere
Towarde Sauce shaping her ioureney
From day to day they ryden in her wey
¶ Amonge al this after his wicked vsage
This marques yet his wife to tempte more
To the vttereste pref of hir corage
Fully to haue experience and lore
If that she were as stedefaste as before
He on a day in open audience
Ful boystously hath seide hir this sentence
¶ Certes Gresilde I hadde ynough plesaunce
To haue you to my wyfe for your godenesse
And for your trouth and for your obeysaunce
Nat for youre lynage ne for your rychesse
But yt is nowe knowen in verrey sothnesse
That in grete lordeshipp if I wel avise
There ys grete soủer/reeigntee in sundry wise
¶ I may nat done as eủer/rey poughman may
My peple me constreyneth for to take
Another wyf and cryen day by dey
And eke the pope rancoure for to slake
consenteth it that dare I vndertake
And truely thus muche I wol you sey
My newe wife ys commynge by the wey
¶ Be stronge of herte and voyde anone hir place
And thilke dower that ye brought to me
Take itte agein I grounte it of my grace
Returneth to your faders hous quod he
Noo man may houe alwey ꝓprosperite
With euen herte I rede you to endure
The stroke of fortune or of auenture
¶ And she agein answerde in patience
My lorde quod she I wote and Wiste alwey
Howe that I swore to your magificence
And my pouerte to wight ne can ne may
Maken comparyson it ys noo nay
I helde me neuer digne in noo manere
To ben youre wife ne in your chambre here
¶ And in this hous there ye me lady made
The high god I take to my witnesse
And as wisely he my soule glade
I hielde me neither lady ne maistresse
But humble ʆser/siruaunte to your worthynesse
And euir shal while my life may dure
Abouen eủer/rey other creature
¶ That ye so longe of your benignitee
Han holde me in honoure and nobley
Where I was naught worthy for to bee
That thonke I god and you whom I prey
Foryelde it you there is nomore to sey
Vn to my fader gladly wol I wende
And with him dwel there to my lyues ende
¶ There I was fustred vp a childe ful smalle
Til I be dede my life there wol I lede
A widowe clene in herte body and al
For seth I yaue to you my maydenhede
And am youre trewe wife it ys to drede
God shelde such a lordes wife to take
Another man to husbonde or to make
¶ And of youre newe wife god of his grace
Soo graunte you welth and ꝓprosꝑper/paritee
For I wol gladly yelde hir my place
In which I was blisful wonte to bee
For seth it liketh you my lorde quod shee
That whilom were al myn hertes reste
That I shal gone . I shal goo whenne ye leste
¶ Bu there as ye me ꝓprofer such dowere
As I firste brought it is wel in my mynde
It were my wretched clothes nothing feire
The which to me nowe were ful harde to fynde
O lord god how gentil and how kinde
Ye semed by your spech and youre visage
The day that maked was oure maryage
¶ But sothe is seide al gate I finde it trewe
For in effecte it is ꝓproued nowe on me
Love is nat olde as whenne yt ys newe
For certes lord for non aduersitee
To dien in the cas it shal nat bee
That in worde or werke I shall repente
That I you yafe myn hert in gode entente
¶ My lorde ye wote that in my faders place
Ye did me strype oute of my poủer/ree wede
And richely ye clad me of youre grace
To you brought I naught elles onte of drede
But feith and nakednesse and maydenhede
But here agein youre clothinge I restore
And eke my wedding rynge for eủer/remore
¶ The remenaunte of youre Iewels redy bee
Within youre chaumber I dare sauely seyne
naked out of faders hous quod shee
I come and naked I muste turne ageyne
Al youre plesaunce wolde I folowe feyne
But yet I hope it be nat youre entente
That I smoklesse onte of youre paleis went
¶ Ye conde nat doo soo dishoneste a thinge
That thilke wombe in which youre children lay
Shulde before the peple in my walkinge
Be seene al bare where fore I you pray
Let me nat like a worme goo by the way
Remembre you myn own lorde so dere
I was youre wife though I vnworthy were
¶ Wherfore in guerdou of my maydenhede
Which that I brought and nat ayein bere
As vouche saufe to yeve me to my mede
But swich a smok as I was wonte to were
That I there with my wry the wombe of here
that was youre wife and here I take my leve
Of you myn own lorde leste I you greve
¶ The smok quod he that thou haste on thy bake
Lette it be stil and bere it forth with thee
But wel vnneth that worde he spak
But went his wey for routh and pitee
Before the folke hir self strypeth shee
And ininhir smok with hede and fete al bare
Towarde hir faders hous she forth is fare
¶ The folkes folowed weping in her wey
And fortune euer they cursen as they gone
But she from weping ket hir yen drye
Ne in this tyme word spake she none
Hir fader that this worde herde anone
Cursed the day and tyme that nature
Shope him to ben a lynes creature
¶ For onte of donte this olde poủer/ree man
Was eủer/ree suspecte of hir mariage
For eủer/ree he demeth seth that yt be gan
That whenne the lord had filled his corage
Him wolde think it was a disꝓproage
to his estae so lowe to alight
And voyden hir as sone as eủer/ree he might
Ayinste his deughter hastely goth hee
For by the noyse of folk he knewe her commynge
And with hir olde cote as it might bee
He coủer/reed hir ful sorowfully wepinge
But on hir body myghte he it nat brynge
For rude was the clooth and she moore of age
By dayes fele than at hir mariage
Thus with hir fader for a certein space
Dwelleth this flour of wifly pacience
That neyther by hir wordes ne hir face
Biforn the folk ne eek in hir absence
Ne shewed she that hir was doon offence
Ne of hir heighe estat no remembrance
Ne hadde she as by hir contenance
No wonder is for in hir grete estat
Hir goost was euere in pleyn humylitee
No tendre mouth noon herte delicat
No pompe no semblant of realtee
But ful of pacient benygnytee
Discreet and pridelees ay honurable
And to hir housbonde euere meke and stable
Men speke of Iob and moost for his hunblenesse
As clerkes whan hem lest konne wel endite
Namely of men but as in soothfastnesse
Thogh clerkes preyse wommen but alite
Ther kan no man in humblesse hym acquite
As wommen kan ne kan be half so trewe
As wommen been but it be falle of newe
¶ . Quinta pars .
Incipit pars Sexta
Fro Boloigne is this Erl of Pavyk come
Of which the fame vp sprong to moore and lesse
And to the peples erys alle and some
Was kouth eek that a newe Markisesse
He with hym broghte in swich pomp and richesse
That neuere was ther seyn with mannes eye
So noble array in al westlumbardye
The Markys which that shoop and knew al this
Er that this Erl was come sente his message
For thilke sely poure Grisildis
And she with humble herte and glad visage
Nat with no swollen thoght in hir corage
Cam at his heste and on hir knees hir sette
And reuerently and wysly she hym grette
Grisilde quod he my wyl is outrely
This mayden that shal wedded been to me
Receyued be tomorwe as really
As it possible is in myn hous to be
And eek that euery wight in his degree
Haue his estat in sittyng and seruyse
And heigh plesance as I kan best deuyse
I haue no wommen suffisant certayn
The chambres for taraye in ordynance
After my lust and ther fore wolde I fayn
That thyn were al swich manere gouernance
Thow knowest eek of old al my plesance
Though thyn array be badde and yuel biseye
Do thow thy deuoir at the leeste weye
Nat oonly lord that I am glad quod she
To doon youre lust but I desire also
Yow for to serue and plese in my degree
With outen feyntyng and shal euere mo
Ne neuere for no wele ne no wo
Ne shal the goost with Inne myn herte stente
To loue yow best with al my trewe entente
And with that word she gan the hous to dighte
And tables for to sette and beddes make
And peyned hir to doon al that she myghte
Preyynge the chambreres for goddes sake
To hasten hem and faste swepe and shake
And she the mooste seruysable of alle
Hath euery chambre arrayed and his halle
Abouten vndren gan this Erl alighte
That with hym broghte thise noble children tweye
For which the peple ran to seen the sighte
Of hire array so richely biseye
And thanne at erst amonges hem they seye
That Walter was no fool thogh that hym leste
To chaunge his wyf for it was for his beste
For she is fairer as they demen alle
Than is Grisilde and moore tendre of age
And fairer fruyt bitwene hem sholde falle
And moore plesant for hir heigh lynage
Hir brother eek so fair was of visage
That hem to seen the peple hath caught plesance
Commendynge now the Markys gouernance
And more plesaunce for her high lynage
Hir brother was soo faire of his age
That him to seeene the peple had caught plesaunce
Commmendinge nowe the marques gouernaunce
¶ O sterne peple vnsadde and euir vntrewe
Euir vndiscrete and chaunginge as a fane
Delitynge eủer/ree in rumur that ys newe
For lyke the mone euir ye wax and wane
One ful of clapping dere yuongh a rane
Youre dome ys fals your constaunce evil pueth
A ful grete foole ys he that on you leueth
¶ Thus seiden sadde folke in that citee
Whenne that the peple gased vp and doun
For they were glad right for the noueltee
To haue a newe lady of her toun
No more of this make I mencioun
But to Gresilde agein I wol me dresse
And tellen hir constaunce and besynesse
¶ Welle Besy was Gresilde in eủer/rey thinge
that to the feste was pertynente
Right naught was she abasshed of hir clothinge
Though they were rude and eke somedele to rente
But with glade chere to the gate ys wente
With other folke to greten the marquesse
And after doth she forth hir besynesse
¶ With ful gald chere the gestes she rescyueth
And buxumly ech in his degree
that noman defante there ꝑper/parceyueth
But eủer/ree they wunder what she might bee
that in so pouʳe arra was for to see
And couth such honoure and reủer/reence
And worthily they preysen her prudence
¶ And al this mene while she ne stente
this mayde and eke hir brother to commende
With al hir herte and benygne entente
Soo wel that noman coude hir pris amende
But atte laste whenne this lordes wende
Too sitte a doun he ganne for to calle
Grisilde as she was besy in the halle
¶ Gresilde quod he as it were in his pley
How liketh the my wife in hir beautee
Right wele my lorde quod she for in gode fey
A feirer sawe I neuer none thenne shee
I pray to god soo yeue you ꝓprosperitee
And so hope I that he wol to you sende
Plesaunce ynough vnto youre lynes ende
¶ o thinge I besech you and warne alsoo
that ye ne pryk with no turmentinge
This tender mayde as ye han doo moo
For she was fustred in her norisshinge
Ful tenderly in her youth pleyinge
She couth nat aduersitee endure
As coude a pouʳe fustred creature
¶ And whenne this Waulter sawe her pacience
Hir glade chere and no malice at alle
And he soo ofte had done hir offencee
And she eủer/ree hir and sad as a wal
Contynuynge eủer/ree hir Innocence oủer/re al
This sturdy marques gan his herte dresse
To rewe vpon hir wifely stedefastenesse
And hire in armes took and gan hir kesse
¶ And she for wonder toke therof noo kepe
She herde naught what worde that he seide
She ferde as she had sterte oute of hir slepe
Til she oute of hir masednesse abreyde
Gresilde quod he by god that for vs deyde
Thou arte my wife and none other I haue
Ne neủer/ree had as god my soule save
¶ This is thy doughter which thou haste supposed
To be my wife and none other feithfully
Shal be myn heire as I haue eủer/ree disposed
Thou bare hir in thy body truely
At Boleyne haue I kepte hem selerly
Take hem agein for thou might nat sey
That thou haste loste eiry of they children twey
¶ And folke that other wife han seid of me
I warne hem well that I han done this dede
For no malice ne for no crueltee
But for to assay the in thy wommanhede
And nat for to slee my children god forbede
But for to kepte hem priuely and stille
Till I thy pʳpoos knewe and al thy wil
¶ And when she herde this aswoun doun she falleth
Pr pitous ioy and after her swownynge
She both hir youge children to hir calleth
And in hir armes pitously wepinge
Embrased bothe tenderly kissinge
Ful like a moder with hir salte teres
She bathed both hir Visage and hir heres
¶ O swich a pitous thinge it was to see
Hir swownynge and hir pitous voys to here
Graunt mercy my goode lorde I thonke yoᵘ qd she
That ye han saued me my childre dere
Nowe rek I neủer/ree to ben dede right here
Seth I stonde in youre loue and in your grace
Noo force of deth ne whenne my spiryte pace
¶ O tender O dere . O yonge chldre myne
Youre woful moder wende stedefastelye
That cruel houndes or some vermyne
Had eten you but god of his mercy
And your benygne fader tendirlye
Hath done you kepe and that same stounde
Al sodeinly she swapte agein to grounde
¶ And ininhir swoun so sadley holdeth shee
Hir children two whenne she hem ebrace
That with grete sleight and difficultee
The children from hir armes they arace
O many a tere on many a pitous face
Doun ranne that stoden hir beside
Vnneth aboute hir they might abyde
¶ Waulter hir taketh vp and hir sorowe gladeth
She riseth al a basshed from hir traunce
And eủer/rey wight hir ioy and feste maketh
Til she agein hath caught hir countenaunce
Waulter her doth so feithful plesaunce
That yt was deintee for to see the chere
Bitwix hem twoo now they ben met in fere
¶ Thise ladyes whenne that they hir tyme say
Han taken hir and in to chambre gone
And strypen hir out of hir rude array
And in a cloth of golde that bright shone
With a crowne of many riche stone
Vpon hir hede they hir in to hal brought
And there she was hounoured as she ought
¶ Thus hath this pitous day a blisful ende
For eủer/rey man and womman done her might
This day in mirth and reuel to dispende
Til on the walken shone the sterres bright
For more solmpne in eủer/rey mannes sight
This feste was and gretter of costage
Thenne was the reuel at the maryage
¶ Ful many a yere in hir ꝓprosperytee
Lyuen thise twoo in concorde and in reste
And richely his doughter maryed hee
Vnto a lorde one of the worthyeste
Of al ytail and thenne in pees and reste
His wyues fader in his course he kepeth
Til that his soul out of his body crepeth
¶ In reste and pees after his faders day
His son entreth in to his heritage
And fortunate was ekee in maryage
Al put he naught his wife in assay
This werlde is nat stronge it is no nay
As it hath ben in olde tymes yore
And herkeneth what the auctoure seith therefore
¶ This story is seid nat htat wyues shulde
Folowe Gresilde as in hymylitee
for it were impossible though they wolde
But that eủer/rey wight in his degree
Sulde be constaunte in aduersitee
This story which he with his stile endyteth
With pacience Gresilde he quiteth
Some tyme there was dwelling in lumbardy
A worthy knight that born was in pavy
In which he lyued in grete ꝓprosperitee
And sexty yere a wifelesse man was hee
And folowed ay his bodyes delyte
On wommen ther was al his appetyte
As doon thise foles that ben seculere
And whenne he was of age sexty yere
Were it for holynesse or for dotage
I can nat seyn but such a grete corage
Had this knight to ben a wedded man
That day and night he doth al that he can
To spyen where he might wedded bee
Preying oure lorde to graunt that hee
Might ones knowe of thilke blisful liffe
That is bitwixe an husbonde and his wife
And for to lyve vnder that holy bonde
With which that god man and womman bonde
None other life he seid is worth a ben
That in this werlde is it a paradys
Thus seid this olde knight that was so wys
And certeinly as soth as god ys kinge
To take a wife it is a glorious thinge
And namely whenne a man is olde and hore
Thenne is a wife the fruyte of his tresore
Thenne shulde he take a yonge wife and a feire
On which he might engendren him an heire
And lede his life in ioy and in solace
Where as thise bachelers singen allas
Whenne they finde eny aduersitee
In love . in which is but childissh vanite
And trewly it semeth wel to bee soo
That bachelers han ofte peyne and woo
On brotil grounde thei bilde and brotilnesse
They finde disceite whenne they wene sekernesse
They lyve but as a bridde or as a beste
In liberte and vnder none areste
There as a wedded man in estate
Lyueth a life blisful and ordynate
Vnder this yok of maryage ybounde
Wel may his herte in ioy and blis habounde
For who can bee so buxome as a wife
Whoo is soo trewe and soo ententife
To kepe him sike and hole as is his make
For wele or woo she wil him nat forsake
She is nat wery him to love or serve
Though he he bedrede til he sterve
And yet some clerkes seyn it is nat soo
Of which he theofraste ys one of thoo
What though theofraste liste to lye
Ne take no wife quod he for husbondrye
As for to spare in housholde thy dispence
A trewe ʆser/siruaunte doth more diligence
Thy gode to kepe thenne doth thine owen wife
For she wol clayme halfe part al hir life
As if that thou be sike soo god me save
Thy verrey frendes or a trewe knave
Wol kepe the bette thenne she that wayteth ay
After thy gode and hath doo many a day
And if thou take a wife
This sentence and an hundred thinges wors
Writeth this man that god his bones cors
And take noo kepe of such vanitee
Defye theofraste and herkene mee
A wife is goddes yefte verrelye
Al other yeftes hardelye
As londes rentes pasture or comune
Or mylles al ben yeftes of fortune
That passen as a shadowe on a wal
But drede nat if pleinly speke I shal
A wife wol laste and in thine hous endure
Wel lenger thenne the luste ꝑper/parauenture
Maryage ys a ful grete sacremente
He that hath no wife I holde him shente
He lyueth helplesse and al desolate
I speke of folk in seculer estate
And herken why I sey nat this for nought
That womman is for mannes help ywrought
The high god whenne he had adam maked
And sawe him allone al bely naked
God of his grete godenesse seid thanne
Let vs nowe make an helpe to this manne
Like to him selfe and thenne he made him eve
Here may ye see and here by may ye preve
That wife is mannes helpe and comforte
His paradys terreste and his disporte
Soo buxume and soo vertuous is shee
They muste nedes lyve in vnitee
O flessh they been and oo flessh as I gesse
Hath but one herte in wele and in distresse
A wyf . A seinte mary benedicitee
Howe might a man han eny adủer/resitee
That hath a wife certes I can nat sey
The blisse which that ys bitwix hem twey
There may no tunge tel ne herte thinke
If he be pore she helpeth him to swynke
She kepeth his gode and wasteth neủer/re a dele
Al that hir husbonde luste she liketh wele
She seith nat ones nay whenne he seith yee
Doo this seith he al redy sir seith shee
O blisful order of wedlok precious
Thou arte soo mery and soo vertuous
And soo commended and yproved eke
That eny man that holte him worth a leke
Vpon his bare knees aught al his life
Thonke his god that him hath sent a wife
Or elles pray to god for to sende
A wife to laste to his lifes ende
For thenne his life is sette in sikernesse
He may nat bee desceyued as I gesse
Soo that he werke after his wyues rede
Thenne may he boldely holden vp his hede
They ben so trewe and alsoo soo wise
For which if thou wilte wirke after the wise
Doo alwey soo as wommen wol the rede
Loo howe that Iacob as thise clerkes rede
By gode counseil of his moder rebek
Bonde the kiddes skynne aboute his neke
For which he his faders blissinge wanne
Loo Iudith eke as the story tellen canne
By wise counseille she goddes peple kepte
And slowe him Olyferne while he slepte
Loo Abygail by gode counseil howe shee
Saued hir husbonde nabal whenne that he
Shulde haue be slayne and loke hester alsoo
By gode counseil deliủer/reed out of woo
The peple of god and made him mardochee
Of Assuer enhaunced for to bee
There is no thing in gree superlatyfe
As seith senek aboue an humble wife
Suffre thy wyues tunge as caton bytte
She shal commaunde and thou shalt suffre itte
And yet she wol obey of curtesye
A wife is keper of thine husbondry
Wel may the sike man bewail and wepe
There that ys no wife the hous to kepe
I warne the if wisely thou wilte wirche
Love wel thi wife as criste loueth his chirche
If thou loueste thy selfe thou louest thy wyfe
No man hateth his flessh but in high lyfe
He fustreth it and that forbede I thee

For al thinge hath tyme as seyne clerkes
As for to putte truste in venus werkes
To eny man for to geten his love
I can nat seyn but grete god above
That knoweth wele that none acte is causlesse
He deme of al for I wol holde my pees
But soth is this that this fresshly May
Hath taken swich impressioun that day
Of pitee on this sike Damyan
That from hir herte she ne dryve can
The remembraunce for to done him ese
Certes thought she whome this thing displese
I rek naughte for here I him assure
To love him beste of eny creature
Though he nomore had thenne his sherte
Loo pitee renneth sone in gentil herte
Here may ye see howe excellent fraunchise
In womman ys whenne they hem narowe avise
Some wise tyraunte ys as there been many one
That han an herte as herde as eny stone
Which wolde haue let him sterve in that place
Wel rather thenne haue graunted him hir grace
And hem reioysen in her cruel pryde
And recken naughte to ben an homecyde
This gentil may fulfilled of pitee
Right of hir honde a letter made shee
In which she gᵃunteth him hir verrey grace
There lakketh naught but onely day ⁊and place
Where that she might vnto his luste suffise
For it shal be right as he wol deuyse
And whenne she sawe hir tyme vpon a day
To visitte this Damyan goth may
And subtilly this letter doun she threste
Vnder hir pilowe rede hit if him leste
She taketh him by the honde and harde twiste
So secretely that no man of it wiste
And bad him be al hole ⁊and forth she wente
To Ianuary whenne he for hir sente
Vp riste Damyan the next morowe
And passed was his sikenesse and his sorowe
He kembeth him he proyneth him ⁊and piketh
He doth al that his lady luste and liketh
And eke to Ianuarye he goth as lowe
As euer did a dogge for the bowe
He is soo plesaunte vnto eủer/rey man
For crafte ys al whoo soo doo it can
That eủer/rey wight is fayne to speke him gode
And fully in his ladyes grace he stode
Thus let I Damyan aboute his nede
And in my tale forth I wol ꝓprocede
Some clerkes holden that felicitee
Stonte in delite and therfore certein hee
This noble Ianuary with al his might
In honeste wise as longeth to a knight
Shope him for to lyve deliciouslye
His housinge his array as honestely
To his degree was maked as a kinges
Amonges other of his honeste thinges
He made a gardein walled al with stone
So feire a gardein note I nowhere none
For oute of doute I verrely suppose
That he that wrote the romaunce of the rose
Ne couth of it the beaute wel deuise
Ne priapus ne might nat suffise
Though he be god of gardeins for to tel
The beaute of this gardein and the wel
That stode vnder a laurer alwey grene
Ful ofte tyme he pluto and his quene
Proserpina and al hir feirye
Desporten hem and maken melodye
Aboute that wel and daunced as men tolde
This noble knight this Ianuary the olde
Such deintee hath he in itte to walke and pley
That he wolde suffre no wight bere the key
Saue he him selfe save of the smale wickette
He bare alwey of siluer a clickette
With which whenne him liste he it shette
And whenne he wolde pay his wife hir dette
In somer sesoun thedir wolde he goo
And May his wife but no wight but thei twoo
And thinge were naught to done a bedde
He in the gardein ꝑper/parfourmed hem and spedde
And in this wise many a mery day
Lyued this Ianuary and this fressh May
But worldly ioy may nought alwey endure left
To Ianuary ne to noo creature
O sodeyn happe . O . fortune vnstable
Lyke to the Scorpyoun soo desceyuable
That flatereste with thine hede when þᵘ wiste stinge
Thi tayl is deth thurgh thine enuemenynge
div.fw: O brotill ioy swete venym queinte
div.l: O brotille ioy swete venym queinte
O monstre that so subtilly canste peinte
Thy yeftes vnder hue of stedefastenesse
That thou desceyueste bothe more and lesse
Whie haste thou thus Ianuary desceyued
That haddeste him for thi ful frende resceyued
And nowe thou haste berefte him both his yien
For sorowe of which desireth he to dyen
Allas this noble Ianuary soo free
Amydde his luste and his ꝓprosperytee
Is woxen blinde and that al sodeinlye
He wepeth and he wailleth pitouslye
And there with al the fire of Ielousye
Leste that his wife shulde fal in some foly
So brente his herte that he wolde fayne
That some man both him and hir had slayn
For neither after his deth ne after his life
Ne wolde he that shee were love ne wife
But eủer/ree leve as a widowe in clothes blake
Soole like the turtil that hath loste hir make
But at the laste after a moneth or twey
His sorowe gan asswage soth to seye
For whenne he wiste it might none other bee
He paciently toke his aduersitee
Saue oute of doute he may nat forgone
That he was Ielous eủer/remore in one
With iesousy he was soo outrageous
That neither in hal ne in none other hous
Ne in other place neuir the moo
He noolde suffre hir too ride ne goo
But he had honde on hir alwey
For which ful ofte wepeth fressh May
That loued Damyan soo benygnelye
That either muste she dyen sodeinly
Or elles she muste haue him at her leste
She waiteth whenne hir hert wolde breste
Vpon that other syde eke Damyan
Becomen ys the sorowfulleste man
That eủer/ree was for neither night ne day
Might he speke oo worde to fressh May
As to his ꝓpropoos of no such mater
But if that Ianuary muste it here
That had an honde vpon hir eủer/remoo
But nathelesse by writing and froo
And priuee signes wiste what he ment
And she knewe eke the fine of his entente
Loo Ianuary what might it the avail
Though thou might see as fer as shippes sail
As good is blinde desceyued for to bee
As too be desceyued whenne a man might see
Loo Argus which that hadde an hundred yien
For al that euer he couth loke or prien
Yet was he blente and by god soo beth moo
That wenen wisely that it be nat soo
Passe ouer is an ease I sey noo more
This fressh May that I spake of soo yore
In warme wex hath printed the clykette
That Ianuary of that smale wykette
By which in too his gardein ofte he wente
And Damyan that knewe al hir entente
The clikette counterfeted priuelye
Ther is nomore to sey but hastelye
Some wunder by this cliket shal betyde
Which ye shulle here if ye wil abyde
O noble Ouydy wel seiste thou god wote
What slette is it though it be longe and hote
That he nyl finde it oute in some manere
By pyramus and thisbe men may lere
Though thei were kept streite longe oủer/ree al
They ben accorded rownynge thurgh a wal
There no wight couth haue founde out such a sleite
But nowe too pʳpoos or that dayes eight
Were passed er the moneth of Iuil fil
That Ianuary hath caught soo grete a wil
Thurgh egging of his wife han to pley
In his gardyn and no wight but they twey
That on a morowe to his may seith hee
Rys vp wife my love my lady free
The turtles voys is herde my lady swete
The winter ys goon with his reynes wete
Come forth nowe with thy yen columbyn
O feirer ben your brestes thenne ys wyne
The gardein ys enclosed al aboute
Come forth my swete spouse out of doute
Thou haste me wounded in myn hert O wife
Noo sporte of the ne knewe I al my life
Come forth and let vs take our desporte
I chese the for my wife and my comforte
Swich olde lewde wordes vsed hee
On Damyan a signe made shee
That he shulde goone before with his clickette
Thus Damyan thenne opened the wickette
And in hee sterte and that in swich manere
That no wight might it seen ner here
And stil he sitte vnder a bussh anone
This Ianuary as blinde as a stone
With may in his honde and no moo
In to his fressh gardeine ys ygoo
And clapte to the wickette sodeinlye
Nowe wife quoth he here nys but thou and I
Thou arte the creature that I beste love
For by that lorde that sitte in heuen aboue
Leuer I had to deyen on a knyfe
Thenne the offende trewe dere wyfe
For goddes sake thenke how I the ches
Nought for no couetise douteles
But onely for the love I hadde to thee
And though that I be olde and may nat see
Beth to me trewe and I wol tel you whye
Thre thinges certes shal ye wynne there bye
Firste love of criste and to you honoure
And al myn herytage toune and toure
I yeve it you make chart s as ye leste
This shal be doone to morowe or sonne reste
Soo wisely god my soul bring in blisse
I pray you firste in couenaunte me kisse
And though I be Ielous witeth me nought
Ye ben soo depe enprinted in my thought
That whenne I consider youre beautee
And there with al the vnlikly elde of me
I may nat certes though I shulde dye
For bere to bee oute of youre companye
For verrey love that ys with outen doute
Nowe kisse me wife and let vs rome aboute
This fressh may whenne she thise wordes herde
Benignely to Ianuary answerde
But firste and forwarde she ganne to wepe
I haue quoth she god wote a soul to kepe
As wel as ye and also myn honoure
And of my wifehode thilke tendir floure
Which I haue ensured in your honde
Whenne that the preste to you my body bonde
Where for I wol answere in this matere
By the leve of you my lorde soo dere
I pray to god that neuer dawe the day
That I ne sterve as foul as womman may
If euer I doo to my kynne that shame
Or elles I empeire soo my name
That I be fals and if I doo that lakke
Doo strype me and put me in a sakke
And in the nexte Riuer doo me drenche
I am a gentil womman and no wenche
What speke ye thus . but men ben eủer/re vntrewe
And wommen han reproufe of you ay newe
Ye han none other contynaunce I leue
But speke to vs of vntruste and repreue
And with that worde she sawe where Damyan
Sat in a bussh and coughen she began
And with hir finger a signe made shee
That Damyan shulde clymbe in too a tree
That charged was with fruyte ⁊and vp he wente
For verrely he knewe al hir entente
And eủer/rey signe that she couth make
Wel bette thenne Ianuary hir owen make
For in a letter she had tolde him al
Of this mater howe he wirch shal
And thus I let him sitte vpon the pery
And Ianuary and may romyng mery
Bright was the day and blewe the firmament
Phebus hath of golde his bemes doun sente
To gladen eủer/rey floure with his warmnesse
He was that tyme in geminis as I gesse
But litle from his declinacioun
Of cancer Iouis exaltacioun
And soo befel that bright morowe tyde
That in that gardein in the ferther syde
Pluto that is kinge of the feiry
And many a lady in his company
Folowing his wife the quene ꝓproserpine
Ech after other as right as a lyne
While that she gadered floures in the mede
In cludyan ye may the story rede
Howe in his grisly carte he hir ette
This kinge of feiry thenne a doune him sette
Vpon a benche of thornes sharp and grene
And right anone thus seide he to the quene
My wife quod he there may no wight sey nay
Experience soo ꝓproueth eủer/rey day
The treson which that wommen do to man
Tenne hundred thousand tel I can
Notable of youre vntrouth and brotilnesse
O Salamon wis and richeste of richesse
Fulfilled of sapience and worldly glory
Ful worthy ben thy wordes to memorye
To eủer/rey wight that witte and reson canne
Thus preiseth he yet the bounte of manne
Among a thousand men yet fonde I one
But of wommen al yet fonde I none
Thus seith the kinge that knoweth yoᵘur wickednesse
And Iesus filius Sidrak as I gesse .
Ne speke of you but selde reủer/reence
I wolde fire and corrupte pestillence
Soo fal vpon youre bodyes yet to night
Ne see ye nat this honourable knight
By cause allas that he is blinde and olde
His owen man shal maken him cokewolde
Loo where he sitteth lechoure in the tree
Nowe wol I graunte of my maieste
Vn to this olde blinde worthy knight
That he shal haue agein his yien sight
Whenne that his wol doone him vilanye
Thenne shal he knowe al hir harlotry
Both in reproof of hir and other moo
Ye sir quod Ꝓproserpina wol ye soo
Nowe by moders sires soule I swere
That I shal yeve hir suffisaunte answere
And al wommen after for hir sake
That though thei ben in eny gilte ytake
With face bolde thei shull hem selfe excuse
And bere hem doun that wol hem accuse
For lak of answere noon of hem shal dyen
Al had a man sene a thing with both his yen
Yet shal we wommen visage itte boldely
And wepe and swere and chide subtilly
So that ye men shul be as lewde as gees
What rekketh me of youre auctoritees
I wote wel that this Iewe this Salamon
Fonde of vs wommen folies many one
But though he ne founde noo gode womman
Yet hath there founde many another man
Wommen ful trewe ful gode and vertuous
Witnesse of hem that dwel in cristes hous
With martirdome they ꝓproued her constaunce
The romayne gestes eke maken remembraunce
Of many a trewe wife alsoo
But sir be nat wroth al be itte soo
Thoo he seide he founde noo gode womman
I pray you taketh the sentence of the man
He mente thus that in soủer/reeigne bountee
Nys noone but god that sitteth in trinitee
Ey for verrey god that ys but one
What make ye so muche of Salamon
What though he were riche and glorious
What though he made a temple goddes hous
Soo made he eke of fals goddes
Howe might he doo a thing that more forbod is
Parde as wele as ye his name enplaster
He was a lechoure and an ydolaster
And in his elde he verrey god forsooke
And if god ne had as seith the booke
Spared him for his faders sake he shoolde
Han loste his reigne rather then he wolde
I sette right nought of his vilanye
That ye of wommen writen a butterflye
I am a womman I muste nedes speke
Or elles swel til myn herte breke
For seth he seide that we ben Iangeleris
As euer muste I hole brooke my tresses
I shal nat spare for no curtesye
To speke hem harme that speke vs villanye
Dame quod this pluto be no lenger wroth
I yeve it vppe but seth I swore myne othe
That I wolde graunte him his sight agein
My worde shal stonde I sey you certein
I am a kinge it sitte me nat to lye
And I a quene quod she of fairye
Hir answere shal she haue I vndertake
Let vs noo moo wordes here of make
For soth I wol no lenger you contrary
Nowe lat vs turne agein to Ianuary
That in the garden with his fressh may
Singeth more mery thenne the popin Iay
You loue I beste and shal and other none
So longe aboute the aleys is he gone
Tyl he was come ageinste thilke pery
Where as this Damyan sitteth ful mery
On high amonge the fressh leues grene
This fressh may that is so fressh and shene
Gan to sike and seid allas my side
Nowe sir seid she for ought that may betide
I muste haue of thoo peres that I see
Or I muste dey so sore longeth mee
To eten of the smale peres grene
Helpe for hir loue that is of heuen quene
I tel you we wommen in my plight
May haue to fruyte soo grete an appetite
That she may dyen but she of it haue
Allas quod he that I ne had here a knave
That couth clymbe allas allas quod he
For I am blinde no force quod she
But wil ye vouchen saufe for goddes sake
The pyry in youre armes for to take
For wele I wote that ye mystruste mee
Thenne shulde I clymbe wel ynough quod she
Soo I my fote may sette on your bakke
Certes quoth he therof shal be noo lak
Myght I you helpe with myn herte blode
He stouped doun and on his bak she stode
And caught hir by a twiste and vp she goth
Lordes I pray you that ye be nat wroth
I can nat glose I am a rude man
And sodeinly anone this Damyan
Gan pullen vp the smok and in thronge
And whenne that pluto sawe this grete wronge
To Ianuary he yave agein his sight
And made him see aswel as eủer/ree he might
And whenne he had caught his sight agein
Was ther neủer/ree man of thinge more feyne
But on his wife his thought was eủer/remoo
Vp to the tree he keste his yien twoo
And sawe that Damyan his wif had dressed
In swich maner as may nat ben expressed
But I wolde speke vncurteisly /
And vp he yave a roringe and a cry
O stronge lady store what dooste thou
And she answerde sir what eilleth you
Hath pacience and reson in youre mynde
I haue you holpe of both youre yien blinde
Vp perel of my soul I shal nat lyen
As me was taughte to helpe wᵗith youre yen
Was no thinge bet to make you to see
Thenne strogle with a man in a tree
God wote I didde it in ful gode entente
Strogle quod he algate in it wente
God yeve you both on shames deth to dyen
He swyued the I sawe it with myn yien
And elles be I honged by the hals
Thenne is quod she my medecyne fals
For certeinly if ye might see
Ye nolde haue seid thise wordes to me
Ye han some glimsinge and no ꝓprofite sight
I see quoth he as wel as eủer/re I might
Thonked be god with both myn yien twoo
And by my trouth he didde the soo
Ye may . ye may . ye quoth she .
This thonke I haue for to make you see
Allas quod she that euer I was soo kinde
Nowe dame quod he lat al passe oute of mynde
Come doune my leef and if I haue myssayde
God help me soo as I am euyl a payde
But by my fader soul I wende haue seyne
Howe that this Damyan has by the leyne
And that thy smok had lyen vpon thy breste
Ye sir quod she ye mowe wene as ye leste
But sir a man that waketh out of his slepe
He may nat sodeinly take kepe
Vpon a thinge and seen it perfitely
Til that he be dawed verrelye
Right soo a man that long hath blinde bee
Ne may nat sodeinly soo wel see
Firste whenne his sight is comen agein
As hee that hath a day or twoo ysein
Til that your sight satled bee a while
There may ful many a sight you begile
Beware I pray you for by heuen kinge
Ful many a man weneth to see a thinge
And it is al another thenne it semeth
He that mysconceyueth mysdemeth
And with that worde she lepte fro the tree
This Ianuary whoo is glad but shee
He kisseth hir and clippeth hir ful ofte
And on hir wombe he striked hir ful softe
And to his paleis home he hath hir ladde
Nowe gode men I pray you to be gladde
Thus endeth here my tale of Ianuarye
God blisse vs and his moder seinte mary
(base) This worthy lymytour/ this noble frere
(base) He made alwey / a manere louryng cheere
(base) Vpon the Somnour/ but for honestee
(base) No vileyns word / as yet to hym spak he
(base) But at the laste / he seyde vnto the wyf
(base) ¶ Dame quod he god yeue yow right good lyf
(base) Ye han heer touched / al so mote I thee
(base) In scole matere / greet difficultee
(base) Ye han seyd muche thyng right wel I seye
(base) But dame / here as we ryden by the weye
(base) Vs nedeth nat to speken / but of game
(base) And lete auctoritees / on goddes name
(base) To prechyng and to scole of clergye
(base) But if it like / to this compaignye
(base) I wol yow / of a Somnour telle a game
(base) Pardee / ye may wel knowe by the name
(base) That of a Somnour / may no good be sayd
(base) I praye / that noon of yow / be ypayd
(base) A somnour / is a rennere vp and doun
(base) With mandementz / for fornicacioun
(base) And is ybet at euery townes ende
(base) ¶ Oure hoost tho spak / a sire ye sholde be hende
(base) And curteys / as a man of youre estaat
(base) In compaignye / we wol no debaat

div.l: (base) Telleth youre tale / and lat the Somnour be
(base) ¶ Nay quod the Somnour / lat hym seye to me
(base) What so hym list whan it comth to my lot
(base) By god / I shal hym quyten euery grot
(base) I shal hym telle / which a gret honour
(base) It is / to be a flaterynge lymytour
(base) And of / many another manere cryme
(base) Which nedeth nat rehercen / for this tyme
(base) And his office / I shal hym telle ywys
(base) ¶ Oure hoost answerde / pees namoore of this
(base) And after this / he seyde vnto the frere
(base) Tel forth youre tale / leeue maister deere
(base) Here endeth the prolog
(base) ¶ And bigynneth his tale
(base) Hic incipit fabula Fratris
(base) Whilom / ther was dwellynge in my contree
(base) An Erchedekne / a man of hy degree
(base) That boldely / dide execucioun
(base) In punysshynge of Fornicacioun
(base) Of wicchecraft and eek of Bawderye
(base) Of diffamacioun / and auoutrye
(base) Of chirche Reues / and of testamentz
(base) Of contractes / and eek of lakke of sacramentz
(base) And eek of many anoþer cryme
(base) Which neediþ not to reherse at þis tyme
(base) Of vsure / and of Symonye also
(base) But certes / lecchours / dide he grettest wo
(base) They sholde syngen if that they were hent
(base) And smale tytheres were foule yschent
(base) If any persoun / wold vpon hem pleyne
(base) Ther myghte asterte hym no pecunial peyne
(base) For smale tithes and for smal offryng
(base) He made the peple ful pitusly to syng
(base) For er the bysschop caght hem with hys hooc
(base) They were in the erchdeknys book /
(base) And thanne had he thurgh hys Iurisdiccion
(base) Power to do on hem correccion
(base) He hadde a Somnour / redy to his hond
(base) A slyer boy / nas noon in Engelond
(base) For subtilly / he hadde his espiaille
(base) That taughte hym / wher hym myghte auaille
(base) He koude spare / of lecchours / oon or two
(base) To techen hym / to foure and twenty mo
(base) For theigh this Somnour / wood were as an hare
(base) To telle his harlotrye / I wol nat spare
(base) For we been / out of his correccioun
(base) They han of vs / no Iurisdiccioun
(base) Ne neuere shullen / terme of hir lyues
(base) ¶ Peter / so been wommen of the Styves
(base) Quod the Somnour / yput out of my cure
(base) ¶ Pees with myschaunce / and with mysauenture
(base) Thus seyde oure hoost / and lat hym telle his tale
(base) Now telleth forth / thogh that the Somnour gale
(base) Ne spareth nat myn owene mayster deere
(base) ¶ This false theef this Somnour / quod the frere
(base) Hadde alwey / baudes redy to his hond
(base) As any hauk to lure in Engelond
(base) That tolde hym / al the secree that they knewe
(base) For hire aqueyntance / was nat come of newe
(base) They weren / hise Approwours pryuely
(base) He took hymself / a greet profit ther by
(base) His maister knew nat alwey / what he wan
(base) Withouten mandement a lewed man
(base) He koude somne / on peyne of cristes curs
(base) And they were glade / for to fille his purs
(base) And make hym / grete festes atte nale
(base) And right as Iudas / hadde purses smale
(base) And was a theef right swich a theef was he
(base) His maister / hadde but half his duetee
(base) He was / if I shal yeuen hym his laude
(base) A theef / and eek a somnour / and a baude
(base) He hadde eek wenches / at his retenue
(base) That wheither that sir Robert / or sire hewe
(base) Or Iakke / or Rauf or who so that it were
(base) That lay by hem / they tolde it in his ere
(base) Thus was the wenche and he / of oon assent
(base) And he wolde fecche / a feyned mandement
(base) And somne hem to Chapitre / bothe two
(base) And pile the man / and lete the wenche go
(base) ¶ Thanne wolde he seye / freend I shal for thy sake
